统计场论第八章

8

Beyond spin waves

8.1 The nonlinear σ\sigmaσ model

Previously we considered low-temperature expansions for discrete spins (Ising, Potts, etc.), in which the low energy excitations are droplets of incorrect spin in a uniform background selected by broken symmetry. These excitations occur at small scales, and are easily described by graphs on the lattice. By contrast, for continuous spins, the lowest energy excitations are long-wavelength Goldstone modes, as discussed in Section 2.4. The thermal excitation of these modes destroys the long-range order in dimensions d≤2d \leq 2d≤2. For ddd close to 2 , the critical temperature must be small, making low-temperature expansions a potential tool for the study of critical phenomena. As we shall demonstrate next, such an approach requires keeping track of the interactions between Goldstone modes.

Consider unit nnn-component spins on the sites of a lattice, i.e.

s⃗(i)=(s1,s2,⋯ ,sn), with ∣s⃗(i)∣2=s12+⋯+sn2=1\begin{equation*} \vec{s}(\mathbf{i})=\left(s_{1}, s_{2}, \cdots, s_{n}\right), \quad \text { with } \quad|\vec{s}(\mathbf{i})|^{2}=s_{1}^{2}+\cdots+s_{n}^{2}=1 \tag{8.1} \end{equation*}s(i)=(s1​,s2​,⋯,sn​), with ∣s(i)∣2=s12​+⋯+sn2​=1​(8.1)​

The usual nearest-neighbor Hamiltonian can be written as

−βH=K∑⟨i⟩s⃗(i)⋅s⃗(j)=K∑⟨i⟩(1−(s⃗(i)−s⃗(j))22).\begin{equation*} -\beta \mathcal{H}=K \sum_{\langle\mathbf{i}\rangle} \vec{s}(\mathbf{i}) \cdot \vec{s}(\mathbf{j})=K \sum_{\langle\mathbf{i}\rangle}\left(1-\frac{(\vec{s}(\mathbf{i})-\vec{s}(\mathbf{j}))^{2}}{2}\right) . \tag{8.2} \end{equation*}−βH=K⟨i⟩∑​s(i)⋅s(j)=K⟨i⟩∑​(1−2(s(i)−s(j))2​).​(8.2)​

At low temperatures, the fluctuations between neighboring spins are small and the difference in Eq. (8.2) can be replaced by a gradient. Assuming a unit lattice spacing,

−βH=−βE0−K2∫ ddx(∇s⃗(x))2\begin{equation*} -\beta \mathcal{H}=-\beta E_{0}-\frac{K}{2} \int \mathrm{~d}^{d} \mathbf{x}(\nabla \vec{s}(\mathbf{x}))^{2} \tag{8.3} \end{equation*}−βH=−βE0​−2K​∫ ddx(∇s(x))2​(8.3)​

where the discrete index i\mathbf{i}i has been replaced by a continuous vector x∈ℜd\mathbf{x} \in \Re^{d}x∈ℜd. A cutoff of Λ≈π\Lambda \approx \piΛ≈π is thus implicit in Eq. (8.3). Ignoring the ground state energy, the partition function is

Z=∫D[s⃗(x)δ(s(x)2−1)]e−K2∫ ddx(s⃗)2\begin{equation*} Z=\int \mathcal{D}\left[\vec{s}(\mathbf{x}) \delta\left(s(\mathbf{x})^{2}-1\right)\right] \mathrm{e}^{-\frac{K}{2} \int \mathrm{~d}^{d} \mathbf{x}(\vec{s})^{2}} \tag{8.4} \end{equation*}Z=∫D[s(x)δ(s(x)2−1)]e−2K​∫ ddx(s)2​(8.4)​

A possible ground state configuration is s⃗(x)=(0,⋯ ,1)\vec{s}(\mathbf{x})=(0, \cdots, 1)s(x)=(0,⋯,1). There are n−1n-1n−1 Goldstone modes describing the transverse fluctuations. To examine the effects of these fluctuations close to zero temperature, set

s⃗(x)=(π1(x),⋯ ,πn−1(x),σ(x))≡(π⃗(x),σ(x))\begin{equation*} \vec{s}(\mathbf{x})=\left(\pi_{1}(\mathbf{x}), \cdots, \pi_{n-1}(\mathbf{x}), \sigma(\mathbf{x})\right) \equiv(\vec{\pi}(\mathbf{x}), \sigma(\mathbf{x})) \tag{8.5} \end{equation*}s(x)=(π1​(x),⋯,πn−1​(x),σ(x))≡(π(x),σ(x))​(8.5)​

where π⃗(x)\vec{\pi}(\mathbf{x})π(x) is an n−1n-1n−1 component vector. The unit length of the spin fixes σ(x)\sigma(\mathbf{x})σ(x) in terms of π⃗(x)\vec{\pi}(\mathbf{x})π(x). For each degree of freedom

∫ds⃗δ(s2−1)=∫−∞∞dπ⃗ dσδ(π2+σ2−1)=∫−∞∞dπ⃗ dσδ[(σ−1−π2)(σ+1−π2)]=∫−∞∞dπ⃗21−π2,\begin{align*} \int \mathrm{d} \vec{s} \delta\left(s^{2}-1\right) & =\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} \mathrm{d} \vec{\pi} \mathrm{~d} \sigma \delta\left(\pi^{2}+\sigma^{2}-1\right) \\ & =\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} \mathrm{d} \vec{\pi} \mathrm{~d} \sigma \delta\left[\left(\sigma-\sqrt{1-\pi^{2}}\right)\left(\sigma+\sqrt{1-\pi^{2}}\right)\right] \tag{8.6}\\ & =\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} \frac{\mathrm{d} \vec{\pi}}{2 \sqrt{1-\pi^{2}}}, \end{align*}∫dsδ(s2−1)​=∫−∞∞​dπ dσδ(π2+σ2−1)=∫−∞∞​dπ dσδ[(σ−1−π2​)(σ+1−π2​)]=∫−∞∞​21−π2​dπ​,​(8.6)​

where we have used the identity δ(ax)=δ(x)/∣a∣\delta(a x)=\delta(x) /|a|δ(ax)=δ(x)/∣a∣. Using this result, the partition function in Eq. (8.4) can be written as

Z∝∫Dπ⃗(x)1−π(x)2e−K2∫ ddx[(∇π⃗)2+(∇1−π2)2]=∫Dπ⃗(x)exp⁡{−∫ddx[K2(∇π⃗)2+K2(∇1−π2)2+ρ2ln⁡(1−π2)]}.\begin{align*} Z & \propto \int \frac{\mathcal{D} \vec{\pi}(\mathbf{x})}{\sqrt{1-\pi(\mathbf{x})^{2}}} \mathrm{e}^{-\frac{K}{2} \int \mathrm{~d}^{d} \mathbf{x}\left[(\nabla \vec{\pi})^{2}+\left(\nabla \sqrt{1-\pi^{2}}\right)^{2}\right]} \\ & =\int \mathcal{D} \vec{\pi}(\mathbf{x}) \exp \left\{-\int \mathrm{d}^{d} \mathbf{x}\left[\frac{K}{2}(\nabla \vec{\pi})^{2}+\frac{K}{2}\left(\nabla \sqrt{1-\pi^{2}}\right)^{2}+\frac{\rho}{2} \ln \left(1-\pi^{2}\right)\right]\right\} . \tag{8.7} \end{align*}Z​∝∫1−π(x)2​Dπ(x)​e−2K​∫ ddx[(∇π)2+(∇1−π2​)2]=∫Dπ(x)exp{−∫ddx[2K​(∇π)2+2K​(∇1−π2​)2+2ρ​ln(1−π2)]}.​(8.7)​

In going from the lattice to the continuum, we have introduced a density ρ=N/V=1/ad\rho=N / V=1 / a^{d}ρ=N/V=1/ad of lattice points. For unit lattice spacing ρ=1\rho=1ρ=1, but for the purpose of renormalization we shall keep an arbitrary ρ\rhoρ. Whereas the original Hamiltonian was quite simple, the one describing the Goldstone modes π⃗(x)\vec{\pi}(\mathbf{x})π(x) is rather complicated. In selecting a particular ground state, the rotational symmetry was broken. The nonlinear terms in Eq. (8.7) ensure that this symmetry is properly reflected when considering only π⃗\vec{\pi}π.

We can expand the nonlinear terms for the effective Hamiltonian in powers of π⃗(x)\vec{\pi}(\mathbf{x})π(x), resulting in a series

βH[π⃗(x)]=βH0+U1+U2+⋯ ,\begin{equation*} \beta \mathcal{H}[\vec{\pi}(\mathbf{x})]=\beta \mathcal{H}_{0}+\mathcal{U}_{1}+\mathcal{U}_{2}+\cdots, \tag{8.8} \end{equation*}βH[π(x)]=βH0​+U1​+U2​+⋯,​(8.8)​

where

βH0=K2∫ ddx(∇π⃗)2\begin{equation*} \beta \mathcal{H}_{0}=\frac{K}{2} \int \mathrm{~d}^{d} \mathbf{x}(\nabla \vec{\pi})^{2} \tag{8.9} \end{equation*}βH0​=2K​∫ ddx(∇π)2​(8.9)​

describes independent Goldstone modes, while

u1=∫ddx[K2(π⃗⋅∇π⃗)2−ρ2π2]\begin{equation*} u_{1}=\int \mathrm{d}^{d} \mathbf{x}\left[\frac{K}{2}(\vec{\pi} \cdot \nabla \vec{\pi})^{2}-\frac{\rho}{2} \pi^{2}\right] \tag{8.10} \end{equation*}u1​=∫ddx[2K​(π⋅∇π)2−2ρ​π2]​(8.10)​

is the first order perturbation when the terms in the series are organized according to powers of T=1/KT=1 / KT=1/K. Since we expect fluctuations ⟨π2⟩∝T,βH0\left\langle\pi^{2}\right\rangle \propto T, \beta \mathcal{H}_{0}⟨π2⟩∝T,βH0​ is

Fig. 8.1 Diagrammatic representation of the two terms in the perturbation u1u_{1}u1​. order of one, the two terms in U1\mathcal{U}_{1}U1​ are order of TTT; remaining terms are order of T2T^{2}T2 and higher. In the language of Fourier modes,

βH0=K2∫ ddq(2π)dq2∣π⃗(q)∣2,U1=−K2∫ ddq1 ddq2 ddq3(2π)3dπα(q1)πα(q2)πβ(q3)πβ(−q1−q2−q3)(q1⋅q3)−ρ2∫ ddq(2π)d∣π⃗(q)∣2.\begin{align*} \beta \mathcal{H}_{0}= & \frac{K}{2} \int \frac{\mathrm{~d}^{d} \mathbf{q}}{(2 \pi)^{d}} q^{2}|\vec{\pi}(\mathbf{q})|^{2}, \\ \mathcal{U}_{1}= & -\frac{K}{2} \int \frac{\mathrm{~d}^{d} \mathbf{q}_{1} \mathrm{~d}^{d} \mathbf{q}_{2} \mathrm{~d}^{d} \mathbf{q}_{3}}{(2 \pi)^{3 d}} \pi_{\alpha}\left(\mathbf{q}_{1}\right) \pi_{\alpha}\left(\mathbf{q}_{2}\right) \pi_{\beta}\left(\mathbf{q}_{3}\right) \pi_{\beta}\left(-\mathbf{q}_{1}-\mathbf{q}_{2}-\mathbf{q}_{3}\right)\left(\mathbf{q}_{1} \cdot \mathbf{q}_{3}\right) \\ & -\frac{\rho}{2} \int \frac{\mathrm{~d}^{d} \mathbf{q}}{(2 \pi)^{d}}|\vec{\pi}(\mathbf{q})|^{2} . \tag{8.11} \end{align*}βH0​=U1​=​2K​∫(2π)d ddq​q2∣π(q)∣2,−2K​∫(2π)3d ddq1​ ddq2​ ddq3​​πα​(q1​)πα​(q2​)πβ​(q3​)πβ​(−q1​−q2​−q3​)(q1​⋅q3​)−2ρ​∫(2π)d ddq​∣π(q)∣2.​(8.11)​

For the non-interacting (quadratic) theory, the correlation functions of the Goldstone modes are

⟨πα(q)πβ(q′)⟩0=δαβ(2π)dδd(q+q′)Kq2\begin{equation*} \left\langle\pi_{\alpha}(\mathbf{q}) \pi_{\beta}\left(\mathbf{q}^{\prime}\right)\right\rangle_{0}=\frac{\delta_{\alpha \beta}(2 \pi)^{d} \delta^{d}\left(\mathbf{q}+\mathbf{q}^{\prime}\right)}{K q^{2}} \tag{8.12} \end{equation*}⟨πα​(q)πβ​(q′)⟩0​=Kq2δαβ​(2π)dδd(q+q′)​​(8.12)​

The resulting fluctuations in real space behave as

⟨π(x)2⟩0=∫ddq(2π)d⟨∣π⃗(q)∣2⟩0=(n−1)K∫1/L1/a ddq(2π)d1q2=(n−1)KKd(a2−d−L2−d)(d−2).\begin{align*} \left\langle\pi(\mathbf{x})^{2}\right\rangle_{0} & \left.=\left.\int \frac{\mathrm{d}^{d} \mathbf{q}}{(2 \pi)^{d}}\langle | \vec{\pi}(\mathbf{q})\right|^{2}\right\rangle_{0}=\frac{(n-1)}{K} \int_{1 / L}^{1 / a} \frac{\mathrm{~d}^{d} \mathbf{q}}{(2 \pi)^{d}} \frac{1}{q^{2}} \tag{8.13}\\ & =\frac{(n-1)}{K} \frac{K_{d}\left(a^{2-d}-L^{2-d}\right)}{(d-2)} . \end{align*}⟨π(x)2⟩0​​=∫(2π)dddq​⟨∣π(q)​2⟩0​=K(n−1)​∫1/L1/a​(2π)d ddq​q21​=K(n−1)​(d−2)Kd​(a2−d−L2−d)​.​(8.13)​

For d>2d>2d>2 the fluctuations are indeed proportional to TTT. However, for d≤2d \leq 2d≤2 they diverge as L→∞L \rightarrow \inftyL→∞. This is a consequence of the Mermin-Wagner theorem on the absence of long range order in d≤2d \leq 2d≤2. Polyakov [Phys. Lett. 59B, 79 (1975)] reasoned that this implies a critical temperature Tc∼O(d−2)T_{c} \sim \mathcal{O}(d-2)Tc​∼O(d−2), and that an RG expansion in powers of TTT may provide a systematic way to explore critical behavior close to two dimensions.

To construct a perturbative RG, consider a spherical Brillouin zone of radius Λ\LambdaΛ, and divide the modes as π⃗(q)=π⃗<(q)+π⃗>(q)\vec{\pi}(\mathbf{q})=\vec{\pi}^{<}(\mathbf{q})+\vec{\pi}^{>}(\mathbf{q})π(q)=π<(q)+π>(q). The modes π⃗<\vec{\pi}^{<}π<involve momenta 0<∣q∣<Λ/b0<|\mathbf{q}|<\Lambda / b0<∣q∣<Λ/b, while we shall integrate over the short wavelength fluctuations π⃗>\vec{\pi}^{>}π>with momenta in the shell Λ/b<∣q∣<Λ\Lambda / b<|\mathbf{q}|<\LambdaΛ/b<∣q∣<Λ. To order of TTT, the coarse-grained Hamiltonian is given by

βH~[π⃗<]=Vδfb0+βH0[π⃗<]+⟨u1[π⃗<+π⃗>]∣0>+O(T2)\begin{equation*} \widetilde{\beta \mathcal{H}}\left[\vec{\pi}^{<}\right]=V \delta f_{b}^{0}+\beta \mathcal{H}_{0}\left[\vec{\pi}^{<}\right]+\left\langle\left. u_{1}\left[\vec{\pi}^{<}+\vec{\pi}^{>}\right]\right|_{0} ^{>}+\mathcal{O}\left(T^{2}\right)\right. \tag{8.14} \end{equation*}βH​[π<]=Vδfb0​+βH0​[π<]+⟨u1​[π<+π>]∣0>​+O(T2)​(8.14)​

where ⟩0>\left\rangle_{0}^{>}\right.⟩0>​indicates averaging over π⃗>\vec{\pi}^{>}π>.

The term proportional to ρ\rhoρ in Eq. (8.11) results in two contributions; one is a constant addition to the free energy (from ⟨(π>)2⟩\left\langle\left(\pi^{>}\right)^{2}\right\rangle⟨(π>)2⟩ ), and the other is simply ρ(π<)2\rho\left(\pi^{<}\right)^{2}ρ(π<)2. (The cross terms proportional to π⃗<⋅π⃗>\vec{\pi}^{<} \cdot \vec{\pi}^{>}π<⋅π>vanish by symmetry.) The quartic part of U1\mathcal{U}_{1}U1​ generates 16 terms as indicated in Fig. 8.3. The contributions on the first and last lines involve either an odd number of π⃗>\vec{\pi}^{>}π>, and hence vanish by symmetry, or come with either 4 or 0 factors of π⃗<\vec{\pi}^{<}π<. The former reproduces the quartic interaction, while the latter adds an overall constant. The more interesting contributions arise from products of two π⃗<\vec{\pi}^{<}π<and two π⃗>\vec{\pi}^{>}π> as depicted in the second and third lines, and are of three types. The first type (appearing on the second line) has the form

⟨U1a⟩0>=2×−K2∫ ddq1 ddq2 ddq3(2π)3d(q1⋅q3)×⟨πα>(q1)πα>(q2)⟩0>πβ<(q3)πβ<(−q1−q2−q3)\begin{align*} \left\langle\mathcal{U}_{1}^{a}\right\rangle_{0}^{>}= & 2 \times \frac{-K}{2} \int \frac{\mathrm{~d}^{d} \mathbf{q}_{1} \mathrm{~d}^{d} \mathbf{q}_{2} \mathrm{~d}^{d} \mathbf{q}_{3}}{(2 \pi)^{3 d}}\left(\mathbf{q}_{1} \cdot \mathbf{q}_{3}\right) \tag{8.15}\\ & \times\left\langle\pi_{\alpha}^{>}\left(\mathbf{q}_{1}\right) \pi_{\alpha}^{>}\left(\mathbf{q}_{2}\right)\right\rangle_{0}^{>} \pi_{\beta}^{<}\left(\mathbf{q}_{3}\right) \pi_{\beta}^{<}\left(-\mathbf{q}_{1}-\mathbf{q}_{2}-\mathbf{q}_{3}\right) \end{align*}⟨U1a​⟩0>​=​2×2−K​∫(2π)3d ddq1​ ddq2​ ddq3​​(q1​⋅q3​)×⟨πα>​(q1​)πα>​(q2​)⟩0>​πβ<​(q3​)πβ<​(−q1​−q2​−q3​)​(8.15)​

The integral over the shell momentum q1\mathbf{q}_{1}q1​ is odd and this contribution is zero. (Two similar vanishing terms arise from contractions with different indices

(Note that in general ρ=N/V=∫0Λddq/(2π)d\rho=N / V=\int_{0}^{\Lambda} \mathrm{d}^{d} \mathbf{q} /(2 \pi)^{d}ρ=N/V=∫0Λ​ddq/(2π)d.) Finally, a renormalization of KKK is obtained from the graph enclosed by the dotted rectangle, as

⟨U1c⟩0>=−K2∫ ddq1 ddq2 ddq3(2π)3d(q1⋅q3)×⟨πα>(q2)πβ>(−q1−q2−q3)⟩0>πα<(q1)πβ<(q3)=K2∫0Λ/b ddq(2π)dq2∣π⃗<(q)∣2×Id(b)K,\begin{align*} \left\langle\mathcal{U}_{1}^{c}\right\rangle_{0}^{>}= & -\frac{K}{2} \int \frac{\mathrm{~d}^{d} \mathbf{q}_{1} \mathrm{~d}^{d} \mathbf{q}_{2} \mathrm{~d}^{d} \mathbf{q}_{3}}{(2 \pi)^{3 d}}\left(\mathbf{q}_{1} \cdot \mathbf{q}_{3}\right) \\ & \times\left\langle\pi_{\alpha}^{>}\left(\mathbf{q}_{2}\right) \pi_{\beta}^{>}\left(-\mathbf{q}_{1}-\mathbf{q}_{2}-\mathbf{q}_{3}\right)\right\rangle_{0}^{>} \pi_{\alpha}^{<}\left(\mathbf{q}_{1}\right) \pi_{\beta}^{<}\left(\mathbf{q}_{3}\right) \tag{8.17}\\ = & \frac{K}{2} \int_{0}^{\Lambda / b} \frac{\mathrm{~d}^{d} \mathbf{q}}{(2 \pi)^{d}} q^{2}\left|\vec{\pi}^{<}(\mathbf{q})\right|^{2} \times \frac{I_{d}(b)}{K}, \end{align*}⟨U1c​⟩0>​==​−2K​∫(2π)3d ddq1​ ddq2​ ddq3​​(q1​⋅q3​)×⟨πα>​(q2​)πβ>​(−q1​−q2​−q3​)⟩0>​πα<​(q1​)πβ<​(q3​)2K​∫0Λ/b​(2π)d ddq​q2∣π<(q)∣2×KId​(b)​,​(8.17)​

where

Id(b)≡∫Λ/bΛddk(2π)d1k2=KdΛd−2(1−b2−d)(d−2)\begin{equation*} I_{d}(b) \equiv \int_{\Lambda / b}^{\Lambda} \frac{\mathrm{d}^{d} \mathbf{k}}{(2 \pi)^{d}} \frac{1}{k^{2}}=\frac{K_{d} \Lambda^{d-2}\left(1-b^{2-d}\right)}{(d-2)} \tag{8.18} \end{equation*}Id​(b)≡∫Λ/bΛ​(2π)dddk​k21​=(d−2)Kd​Λd−2(1−b2−d)​​(8.18)​

The coarse-grained Hamiltonian in Eq. (8.14) now equals

βH~[π⃗<]=Vδfb0+Vδfb1+K2(1+Id(b)K)∫0Λ/b ddq(2π)dq2∣π⃗<(q)∣2+K2∫ ddq1 ddq2 ddq3(2π)3dπα<(q1)πα<(q2)πβ<(q3)πβ<(−q1−q2−q3)(q1⋅q3)−ρ2∫0Λ/b ddq(2π)d∣π⃗<(q)∣2×[1−(1−b−d)]+O(T2).\begin{align*} & \widetilde{\beta \mathcal{H}}\left[\vec{\pi}^{<}\right]=V \delta f_{b}^{0}+V \delta f_{b}^{1}+\frac{K}{2}\left(1+\frac{I_{d}(b)}{K}\right) \int_{0}^{\Lambda / b} \frac{\mathrm{~d}^{d} \mathbf{q}}{(2 \pi)^{d}} q^{2}\left|\vec{\pi}^{<}(\mathbf{q})\right|^{2} \\ & +\frac{K}{2} \int \frac{\mathrm{~d}^{d} \mathbf{q}_{1} \mathrm{~d}^{d} \mathbf{q}_{2} \mathrm{~d}^{d} \mathbf{q}_{3}}{(2 \pi)^{3 d}} \pi_{\alpha}^{<}\left(\mathbf{q}_{1}\right) \pi_{\alpha}^{<}\left(\mathbf{q}_{2}\right) \pi_{\beta}^{<}\left(\mathbf{q}_{3}\right) \pi_{\beta}^{<}\left(-\mathbf{q}_{1}-\mathbf{q}_{2}-\mathbf{q}_{3}\right)\left(\mathbf{q}_{1} \cdot \mathbf{q}_{3}\right) \\ & -\frac{\rho}{2} \int_{0}^{\Lambda / b} \frac{\mathrm{~d}^{d} \mathbf{q}}{(2 \pi)^{d}}\left|\vec{\pi}^{<}(\mathbf{q})\right|^{2} \times\left[1-\left(1-b^{-d}\right)\right]+\mathcal{O}\left(T^{2}\right) . \tag{8.19} \end{align*}​βH​[π<]=Vδfb0​+Vδfb1​+2K​(1+KId​(b)​)∫0Λ/b​(2π)d ddq​q2∣π<(q)∣2+2K​∫(2π)3d ddq1​ ddq2​ ddq3​​πα<​(q1​)πα<​(q2​)πβ<​(q3​)πβ<​(−q1​−q2​−q3​)(q1​⋅q3​)−2ρ​∫0Λ/b​(2π)d ddq​∣π<(q)∣2×[1−(1−b−d)]+O(T2).​(8.19)​

The most important consequence of coarse graining is the change of the stiffness coefficient KKK to

K~=K(1+Id(b)K).\begin{equation*} \widetilde{K}=K\left(1+\frac{I_{d}(b)}{K}\right) . \tag{8.20} \end{equation*}K=K(1+KId​(b)​).​(8.20)​

After rescaling, x′=x/b\mathbf{x}^{\prime}=\mathbf{x} / bx′=x/b, and renormalizing, π⃗′(x)=π⃗<(x)/ζ\vec{\pi}^{\prime}(\mathbf{x})=\vec{\pi}^{<}(\mathbf{x}) / \zetaπ′(x)=π<(x)/ζ, we obtain the renormalized Hamiltonian in real space as

−βH′=−Vδfb0−Vδfb1−K~bd−2ζ22∫ ddx′(∇′π′)2−Kbd−2ζ42∫ ddx′(π⃗′(x′)∇π⃗′(x′))2+ρζ22∫ ddx′π′(x′)2+O(T2)\begin{align*} -\beta \mathcal{H}^{\prime}= & -V \delta f_{b}^{0}-V \delta f_{b}^{1}-\frac{\widetilde{K} b^{d-2} \zeta^{2}}{2} \int \mathrm{~d}^{d} \mathbf{x}^{\prime}\left(\nabla^{\prime} \pi^{\prime}\right)^{2} \\ & -\frac{K b^{d-2} \zeta^{4}}{2} \int \mathrm{~d}^{d} \mathbf{x}^{\prime}\left(\vec{\pi}^{\prime}\left(\mathbf{x}^{\prime}\right) \nabla \vec{\pi}^{\prime}\left(\mathbf{x}^{\prime}\right)\right)^{2}+\frac{\rho \zeta^{2}}{2} \int \mathrm{~d}^{d} \mathbf{x}^{\prime} \pi^{\prime}\left(\mathbf{x}^{\prime}\right)^{2}+\mathcal{O}\left(T^{2}\right) \tag{8.21} \end{align*}−βH′=​−Vδfb0​−Vδfb1​−2Kbd−2ζ2​∫ ddx′(∇′π′)2−2Kbd−2ζ4​∫ ddx′(π′(x′)∇π′(x′))2+2ρζ2​∫ ddx′π′(x′)2+O(T2)​(8.21)​

The easiest method for obtaining the rescaling factor ζ\zetaζ is to take advantage of the rotational symmetry of spins. After averaging over the short wavelength modes, the spin is

⟨s⃗~⟩0>=⟨(π1<+π1>,⋯ ,1−(π⃗<+π⃗>)2)∣0>=(π1<,⋯ ,1−(π⃗<)22−⟨(π⃗>)22⟩0>+⋯ )=(1−⟨(π⃗>)22⟩0>+O(T2))(π1<,⋯ ,1−(π⃗<)2).\begin{align*} \langle\widetilde{\vec{s}}\rangle_{0}^{>} & =\left\langle\left.\left(\pi_{1}^{<}+\pi_{1}^{>}, \cdots, \sqrt{1-\left(\vec{\pi}^{<}+\vec{\pi}^{>}\right)^{2}}\right)\right|_{0} ^{>}\right. \\ & =\left(\pi_{1}^{<}, \cdots, 1-\frac{\left(\vec{\pi}^{<}\right)^{2}}{2}-\left\langle\frac{\left(\vec{\pi}^{>}\right)^{2}}{2}\right\rangle_{0}^{>}+\cdots\right) \tag{8.22}\\ & =\left(1-\left\langle\frac{\left(\vec{\pi}^{>}\right)^{2}}{2}\right\rangle_{0}^{>}+\mathcal{O}\left(T^{2}\right)\right)\left(\pi_{1}^{<}, \cdots, \sqrt{1-\left(\vec{\pi}^{<}\right)^{2}}\right) . \end{align*}⟨s⟩0>​​=⟨(π1<​+π1>​,⋯,1−(π<+π>)2​)​0>​=(π1<​,⋯,1−2(π<)2​−⟨2(π>)2​⟩0>​+⋯)=(1−⟨2(π>)2​⟩0>​+O(T2))(π1<​,⋯,1−(π<)2​).​(8.22)​

We thus identify

ζ=1−⟨(π⃗>)22⟩0>+O(T2)=1−(n−1)2Id(b)K+O(T2)\begin{equation*} \zeta=1-\left\langle\frac{(\vec{\pi}>)^{2}}{2}\right\rangle_{0}^{>}+\mathcal{O}\left(T^{2}\right)=1-\frac{(n-1)}{2} \frac{I_{d}(b)}{K}+\mathcal{O}\left(T^{2}\right) \tag{8.23} \end{equation*}ζ=1−⟨2(π>)2​⟩0>​+O(T2)=1−2(n−1)​KId​(b)​+O(T2)​(8.23)​

as the length of the coarse-grained spin. The renormalized coupling constant in Eq. (8.21) is now obtained from

K′=bd−2ζ2K~=bd−2[1−n−12KId(b)]2K[1+1KId(b)]=bd−2K[1−n−2KId(b)+O(1K2)].\begin{align*} K^{\prime} & =b^{d-2} \zeta^{2} \widetilde{K} \\ & =b^{d-2}\left[1-\frac{n-1}{2 K} I_{d}(b)\right]^{2} K\left[1+\frac{1}{K} I_{d}(b)\right] \tag{8.24}\\ & =b^{d-2} K\left[1-\frac{n-2}{K} I_{d}(b)+\mathcal{O}\left(\frac{1}{K^{2}}\right)\right] . \end{align*}K′​=bd−2ζ2K=bd−2[1−2Kn−1​Id​(b)]2K[1+K1​Id​(b)]=bd−2K[1−Kn−2​Id​(b)+O(K21​)].​(8.24)​

For infinitesimal rescaling, b=(1+δℓ)b=(1+\delta \ell)b=(1+δℓ), the shell integral results in

Id(b)=KdΛd−2δℓ.\begin{equation*} I_{d}(b)=K_{d} \Lambda^{d-2} \delta \ell . \tag{8.25} \end{equation*}Id​(b)=Kd​Λd−2δℓ.​(8.25)​

The differential recursion relation corresponding to Eq. (8.24) is thus

dK dℓ=(d−2)K−(n−2)KdΛd−2\begin{equation*} \frac{\mathrm{d} K}{\mathrm{~d} \ell}=(d-2) K-(n-2) K_{d} \Lambda^{d-2} \tag{8.26} \end{equation*} dℓdK​=(d−2)K−(n−2)Kd​Λd−2​(8.26)​

Alternatively, the scaling of temperature T=K−1T=K^{-1}T=K−1 is

dT dℓ=−1K2 dK dℓ=−(d−2)T+(n−2)KdΛd−2T2.\begin{equation*} \frac{\mathrm{d} T}{\mathrm{~d} \ell}=-\frac{1}{K^{2}} \frac{\mathrm{~d} K}{\mathrm{~d} \ell}=-(d-2) T+(n-2) K_{d} \Lambda^{d-2} T^{2} . \tag{8.27} \end{equation*} dℓdT​=−K21​ dℓ dK​=−(d−2)T+(n−2)Kd​Λd−2T2.​(8.27)​

It may appear that we should also keep track of the evolution of the coefficients of the two terms in U1\mathcal{U}_{1}U1​ under RG. In fact, spherical symmetry ensures that the coefficient of the quartic term is precisely the same as KKK at all orders. The apparent difference between the two in Eq. (8.21) is of order of O(T2)\mathcal{O}\left(T^{2}\right)O(T2), and will vanish when all terms at this order are included. The coefficient of the second order term in U1\mathcal{U}_{1}U1​ merely tracks the density of points and also has trivial renormalization.

The behavior of temperature under RG changes drastically at d=2d=2d=2. For d<2d<2d<2, the linear flow is away from zero, indicating that the ordered phase is unstable and there is no broken symmetry. For d>2d>2d>2, small TTT flows back to zero, indicating that the ordered phase is stable. The flows for d=2d=2d=2 are controlled by the second ordered term which changes sign at n=2n=2n=2. For n>2n>2n>2 the flow is towards high temperatures, indicating that Heisenberg and higher spin models are disordered. The situation for n=2n=2n=2 is ambiguous, and it can in fact be shown that dT/dℓ\mathrm{d} T / \mathrm{d} \elldT/dℓ is zero to all orders. This special case will be discussed in more detail in the next section. For d>2d>2d>2 and n>2n>2n>2, there is a phase transition at the fixed point,

T∗=ϵ(n−2)KdΛd−2=2πϵ(n−2)+O(ϵ2)\begin{equation*} T^{*}=\frac{\epsilon}{(n-2) K_{d} \Lambda^{d-2}}=\frac{2 \pi \epsilon}{(n-2)}+\mathcal{O}\left(\epsilon^{2}\right) \tag{8.28} \end{equation*}T∗=(n−2)Kd​Λd−2ϵ​=(n−2)2πϵ​+O(ϵ2)​(8.28)​

where ϵ=d−2\epsilon=d-2ϵ=d−2 is used as a small parameter. The recursion relation at order of ϵ\epsilonϵ is

dT dℓ=−ϵT+(n−2)2πT2\begin{equation*} \frac{\mathrm{d} T}{\mathrm{~d} \ell}=-\epsilon T+\frac{(n-2)}{2 \pi} T^{2} \tag{8.29} \end{equation*} dℓdT​=−ϵT+2π(n−2)​T2​(8.29)​

Stability of the fixed point is determined by the linearized recursion relation

dδT dℓ∣T∗=[−ϵ+(n−2)πT∗]δT=[−ϵ+2ϵ]δT=ϵδT,⟹yt=ϵ\begin{equation*} \left.\frac{\mathrm{d} \delta T}{\mathrm{~d} \ell}\right|_{T^{*}}=\left[-\epsilon+\frac{(n-2)}{\pi} T^{*}\right] \delta T=[-\epsilon+2 \epsilon] \delta T=\epsilon \delta T, \quad \Longrightarrow \quad y_{t}=\epsilon \tag{8.30} \end{equation*} dℓdδT​​T∗​=[−ϵ+π(n−2)​T∗]δT=[−ϵ+2ϵ]δT=ϵδT,⟹yt​=ϵ​(8.30)​

The thermal eigenvalue, and the resulting exponents ν=1/ϵ\nu=1 / \epsilonν=1/ϵ, and α=2−(2+\alpha=2-(2+α=2−(2+ ϵ)/ϵ≈−2/ϵ\epsilon) / \epsilon \approx-2 / \epsilonϵ)/ϵ≈−2/ϵ, are independent of nnn at this order.

The magnetic eigenvalue can be obtained by adding a term −h⃗⋅∫ ddxs⃗(x)-\vec{h} \cdot \int \mathrm{~d}^{d} \mathbf{x} \vec{s}(\mathbf{x})−h⋅∫ ddxs(x), to the Hamiltonian. Under the action of RG, h′=bdζh≡byhhh^{\prime}=b^{d} \zeta h \equiv b^{y_{h}} hh′=bdζh≡byh​h, with

byh=bd[1−n−12KId(b)].\begin{equation*} b^{y_{h}}=b^{d}\left[1-\frac{n-1}{2 K} I_{d}(b)\right] . \tag{8.31} \end{equation*}byh​=bd[1−2Kn−1​Id​(b)].​(8.31)​

For an infinitesimal rescaling

1+yhδℓ=(1+dδℓ)(1−n−12T∗KdΛd−2δℓ)\begin{equation*} 1+y_{h} \delta \ell=(1+d \delta \ell)\left(1-\frac{n-1}{2} T^{*} K_{d} \Lambda^{d-2} \delta \ell\right) \tag{8.32} \end{equation*}1+yh​δℓ=(1+dδℓ)(1−2n−1​T∗Kd​Λd−2δℓ)​(8.32)​

leading to

yh=d−n−12(n−2)ϵ=1+n−32(n−2)ϵ+O(ϵ2),\begin{equation*} y_{h}=d-\frac{n-1}{2(n-2)} \epsilon=1+\frac{n-3}{2(n-2)} \epsilon+\mathcal{O}\left(\epsilon^{2}\right), \tag{8.33} \end{equation*}yh​=d−2(n−2)n−1​ϵ=1+2(n−2)n−3​ϵ+O(ϵ2),​(8.33)​

which does depend on nnn. Using exponent identities, we find

η=2+d−2yh=ϵn−2.\begin{equation*} \eta=2+d-2 y_{h}=\frac{\epsilon}{n-2} . \tag{8.34} \end{equation*}η=2+d−2yh​=n−2ϵ​.​(8.34)​

The exponent η\etaη is zero at the lowest order in a 4−d4-d4−d expansion, but appears at first order in the vicinity of two dimensions. The actual values of the exponents calculated at this order are not very satisfactory.

8.2 Topological defects in the XY model

As stated in the previous section, thermal excitation of Goldstone modes destroys spontaneous order in two-dimensional models with a broken continuous symmetry. The RG study of the nonlinear σ\sigmaσ model confirms that the transition temperature of nnn-component spins vanishes as T∗=2πϵ/(n−2)T^{*}=2 \pi \epsilon /(n-2)T∗=2πϵ/(n−2) for ϵ=(d−2)→0\epsilon=(d-2) \rightarrow 0ϵ=(d−2)→0. However, the same RG procedure appears to suggest a different behavior for n=2n=2n=2. The first indication of unusual behavior for the two-dimensional spin models appeared in an analysis of high-temperature series [H.E. Stanley and T.A. Kaplan, Phys. Rev. Lett. 17, 913 (1966)]. The series results strongly suggested the divergence of susceptibility at a finite temperature, seemingly in contradiction with the absence of symmetry breaking. It was indeed this contradiction that led Wegner to explore the possibility of a phase transition without symmetry breaking [F.J. Wegner, J. Math. Phys. 12, 2259 (1971)]. The Z2Z_{2}Z2​ lattice gauge theory, discussed in Section 7.5 as the dual of the three-dimensional Ising model, realizes such a possibility. The two phases of the Z2Z_{2}Z2​ gauge theory are characterized by different functional forms for the decay of an appropriate correlation function (the Wilson loop). We can similarly examine the asymptotic behavior of the spin-spin correlation functions of the XY model at high and low temperatures.

A high-temperature expansion for the correlation function for the XY model on a lattice is constructed from

⟨s⃗0⋅s⃗r⟩=⟨cos⁡(θ0−θr)⟩=1Z∏i=1N(∫02π dθi2π)cos⁡(θ0−θr)eK∑⟨i,j⟩cos⁡(θi−θj)=1Z∏i=1N(∫02π dθi2π)cos⁡(θ0−θr)∏⟨i,j⟩[1+Kcos⁡(θi−θj)+O(K2)].\begin{align*} \left\langle\vec{s}_{\mathbf{0}} \cdot \vec{s}_{\mathbf{r}}\right\rangle & =\left\langle\cos \left(\theta_{0}-\theta_{\mathbf{r}}\right)\right\rangle=\frac{1}{Z} \prod_{i=1}^{N}\left(\int_{0}^{2 \pi} \frac{\mathrm{~d} \theta_{i}}{2 \pi}\right) \cos \left(\theta_{0}-\theta_{\mathbf{r}}\right) \mathrm{e}^{K \sum_{\langle i, j\rangle} \cos \left(\theta_{i}-\theta_{j}\right)} \\ & =\frac{1}{Z} \prod_{i=1}^{N}\left(\int_{0}^{2 \pi} \frac{\mathrm{~d} \theta_{i}}{2 \pi}\right) \cos \left(\theta_{0}-\theta_{\mathbf{r}}\right) \prod_{\langle i, j\rangle}\left[1+K \cos \left(\theta_{i}-\theta_{j}\right)+\mathcal{O}\left(K^{2}\right)\right] . \tag{8.35} \end{align*}⟨s0​⋅sr​⟩​=⟨cos(θ0​−θr​)⟩=Z1​i=1∏N​(∫02π​2π dθi​​)cos(θ0​−θr​)eK∑⟨i,j⟩​cos(θi​−θj​)=Z1​i=1∏N​(∫02π​2π dθi​​)cos(θ0​−θr​)⟨i,j⟩∏​[1+Kcos(θi​−θj​)+O(K2)].​(8.35)​

The expansion for the partition function is similar, except for the absence of the factor cos⁡(θ0−θr)\cos \left(\theta_{0}-\theta_{\mathbf{r}}\right)cos(θ0​−θr​). To the lowest order in KKK, each bond on the lattice contributes either a factor of one, or Kcos⁡(θi−θj)K \cos \left(\theta_{i}-\theta_{j}\right)Kcos(θi​−θj​). Since,

∫02π dθ12πcos⁡(θ1−θ2)=0\begin{equation*} \int_{0}^{2 \pi} \frac{\mathrm{~d} \theta_{1}}{2 \pi} \cos \left(\theta_{1}-\theta_{2}\right)=0 \tag{8.36} \end{equation*}∫02π​2π dθ1​​cos(θ1​−θ2​)=0​(8.36)​

any graph with a single bond emanating from an internal site vanishes. For the numerator of Eq. (8.35) to be non-zero, there must be bonds originating from the external points at 0\mathbf{0}0 and r\mathbf{r}r. Integrating over an internal point with two bonds leads to

∫02π dθ22πcos⁡(θ1−θ2)cos⁡(θ2−θ3)=12cos⁡(θ1−θ3)\begin{equation*} \int_{0}^{2 \pi} \frac{\mathrm{~d} \theta_{2}}{2 \pi} \cos \left(\theta_{1}-\theta_{2}\right) \cos \left(\theta_{2}-\theta_{3}\right)=\frac{1}{2} \cos \left(\theta_{1}-\theta_{3}\right) \tag{8.37} \end{equation*}∫02π​2π dθ2​​cos(θ1​−θ2​)cos(θ2​−θ3​)=21​cos(θ1​−θ3​)​(8.37)​

The leading graph that contributes to Eq. (8.35) is the shortest path (of length rrr ) connecting the points 0\mathbf{0}0 and r\mathbf{r}r. Since integrating over the end points gives

∫02π dθ0dθr(2π)2cos⁡(θ0−θr)2=12\begin{equation*} \int_{0}^{2 \pi} \frac{\mathrm{~d} \theta_{\mathbf{0}} \mathrm{d} \theta_{\mathbf{r}}}{(2 \pi)^{2}} \cos \left(\theta_{\mathbf{0}}-\theta_{\mathbf{r}}\right)^{2}=\frac{1}{2} \tag{8.38} \end{equation*}∫02π​(2π)2 dθ0​dθr​​cos(θ0​−θr​)2=21​​(8.38)​

each bond along the path contributes (K/2)(K / 2)(K/2). (In constructing graphs for the partition function, there is an additional factor of 2 for every loop.) Thus to lowest order

⟨s⃗0⋅s⃗r⟩≈(K2)r=e−r/ξ, with ξ≈1ln⁡(2/K)\begin{equation*} \left\langle\vec{s}_{\mathbf{0}} \cdot \vec{s}_{\mathbf{r}}\right\rangle \approx\left(\frac{K}{2}\right)^{r}=\mathrm{e}^{-r / \xi}, \quad \text { with } \quad \xi \approx \frac{1}{\ln (2 / K)} \tag{8.39} \end{equation*}⟨s0​⋅sr​⟩≈(2K​)r=e−r/ξ, with ξ≈ln(2/K)1​​(8.39)​

and the disordered high-temperature phase is characterized by an exponential decay of correlations. (We have assumed that the path of shortest length is unique. Along a particular direction, the multiplicity of shortest lattice paths typically grows exponentially with rrr, thus modifying the correlation length, but not the exponential decay which is generic to all spin systems.)

At low temperatures, the cost of small fluctuations around the ground state is obtained by a quadratic expansion, which gives K∫ ddx(∇θ)2/2K \int \mathrm{~d}^{d} \mathbf{x}(\nabla \theta)^{2} / 2K∫ ddx(∇θ)2/2 in the continuum limit. The standard rules of Gaussian integration yield,

⟨s⃗0⋅s⃗r⟩=⟨Rei(θ0−θr)⟩=Rexp⁡[−12⟨(θ0−θr)2⟩].\begin{equation*} \left\langle\vec{s}_{\mathbf{0}} \cdot \vec{s}_{\mathbf{r}}\right\rangle=\left\langle\mathfrak{R} \mathrm{e}^{\mathrm{i}\left(\theta_{0}-\theta_{\mathbf{r}}\right)}\right\rangle=\mathfrak{R} \exp \left[-\frac{1}{2}\left\langle\left(\theta_{\mathbf{0}}-\theta_{\mathbf{r}}\right)^{2}\right\rangle\right] . \tag{8.40} \end{equation*}⟨s0​⋅sr​⟩=⟨Rei(θ0​−θr​)⟩=Rexp[−21​⟨(θ0​−θr​)2⟩].​(8.40)​

In two dimensions, the Gaussian fluctuations grow as

12⟨(θ0−θr)2⟩=12πKln⁡(ra)\begin{equation*} \frac{1}{2}\left\langle\left(\theta_{0}-\theta_{\mathbf{r}}\right)^{2}\right\rangle=\frac{1}{2 \pi K} \ln \left(\frac{r}{a}\right) \tag{8.41} \end{equation*}21​⟨(θ0​−θr​)2⟩=2πK1​ln(ar​)​(8.41)​

where aaa is a short distance cutoff (of the order of the lattice spacing). Hence, at low temperatures,

⟨s⃗0⋅s⃗r⟩≈(ar)12πK\begin{equation*} \left\langle\vec{s}_{0} \cdot \vec{s}_{\mathbf{r}}\right\rangle \approx\left(\frac{a}{r}\right)^{\frac{1}{2 \pi K}} \tag{8.42} \end{equation*}⟨s0​⋅sr​⟩≈(ra​)2πK1​​(8.42)​

i.e. the decay of correlations is algebraic rather than exponential. A power law decay of correlations implies self-similarity (no correlation length), and is usually associated with a critical point. Here it arises from the logarithmic growth of angular fluctuations, which is specific to two dimensions.

The distinct asymptotic decays of correlations at high and low temperatures allows for the possibility of a finite temperature phase transition separating the two regimes. However, the arguments put forward above are not specific to the XY model. Any continuous spin model will exhibit exponential decay of correlations at high temperature, and a power law decay in a low-temperature Gaussian approximation. To show that the Gaussian behavior persists at finite temperatures, we must prove that it is not modified by the additional terms in the gradient expansion. Quartic terms, such as ∫ddx(∇θ)4\int \mathrm{d}^{d} \mathbf{x}(\nabla \theta)^{4}∫ddx(∇θ)4, generate interactions between the Goldstone modes. The relevance of these interactions was probed in the previous section using the nonlinear σ\sigmaσ model. The zero temperature fixed point in d=2d=2d=2 is unstable for all n>2n>2n>2, but apparently stable for n=2n=2n=2. (There is only one branch of Goldstone modes for n=2n=2n=2. It is the interactions between different branches of these modes for n>2n>2n>2 that leads to instability towards high-temperature behavior.) The low-temperature phase of the XY model is said to possess quasi-long range order, as opposed to true long range order that accompanies a finite magnetization.

What is the mechanism for the disordering of the quasi-long range ordered phase? As the RG study suggests that higher order terms in the gradient expansion are not relevant, we must search for other operators. The gradient expansion describes the energy cost of small deformations around the ground state, and applies to configurations that can be continuously deformed to the uniformly ordered state. Kosterlitz and Thouless [J. Phys. C 6, 1181 (1973)] suggested that the disordering is caused by topological defects that can not be regarded as simple deformations of the ground state. Since the angle describing the orientation of a spin is undefined up to an integer multiple of 2π2 \pi2π, it is possible to construct spin configurations for which in going around a closed path the angle rotates by 2πn2 \pi n2πn. The integer nnn is the topological charge enclosed by the path. Because of the discrete nature of this charge, it is impossible to continuously deform to the uniformly ordered state in which the charge is zero. (More generally, topological defects arise in any model with a compact group describing the order parameter.)

The elementary defect, or vortex, has unit charge. In completing a circle centered on the defect the orientation of the spin changes by ±2π\pm 2 \pi±2π. If the radius rrr, of the circle is sufficiently large, the variations in angle will be small and the lattice structure can be ignored. By symmetry, ∇θ\nabla \theta∇θ has a uniform magnitude, and points along the circle (i.e. perpendicular to the radial vector). The magnitude of the distortion is obtained from

∮∇θ⋅ds⃗=dθ dr(2πr)=2πn,⟹ dθ dr=nr.\begin{equation*} \oint \nabla \theta \cdot \mathrm{d} \vec{s}=\frac{\mathrm{d} \theta}{\mathrm{~d} r}(2 \pi r)=2 \pi n, \quad \Longrightarrow \quad \frac{\mathrm{~d} \theta}{\mathrm{~d} r}=\frac{n}{r} . \tag{8.43} \end{equation*}∮∇θ⋅ds= drdθ​(2πr)=2πn,⟹ dr dθ​=rn​.​(8.43)​

Since ∇θ\nabla \theta∇θ is a radial vector, it can be written as

∇θ=n(−yr2,+xr2,0)=−nrr^×z^=−n∇×(z^ln⁡r).\begin{equation*} \nabla \theta=n\left(-\frac{y}{r^{2}},+\frac{x}{r^{2}}, 0\right)=-\frac{n}{r} \widehat{r} \times \widehat{z}=-n \nabla \times(\widehat{z} \ln r) . \tag{8.44} \end{equation*}∇θ=n(−r2y​,+r2x​,0)=−rn​r×z=−n∇×(zlnr).​(8.44)​

Here, r^\widehat{r}r and z^\widehat{z}z are unit vectors, respectively, in the plane and perpendicular to it, and a⃗×b⃗\vec{a} \times \vec{b}a×b indicates the cross product of the two vectors. This (continuum) approximation fails close to the center (core) of the vortex, where the lattice structure is important.

Fig. 8.4 The two elementary vortices in the XY model.

The energy cost of a single vortex of charge nnn has contributions from the core region, as well as from the relatively uniform distortions away from the center. The distinction between regions inside and outside the core is arbitrary, and, for simplicity, we shall use a circle of radius aaa to distinguish the two, i.e.

βEn=βEn0(a)+K2∫a d2x(∇θ)2=βEn0(a)+K2∫aL(2πr dr)(nr)2=βEn0(a)+πKn2ln⁡(La).\begin{align*} \beta \mathcal{E}_{n} & =\beta \mathcal{E}_{n}^{0}(a)+\frac{K}{2} \int_{a} \mathrm{~d}^{2} \mathbf{x}(\nabla \theta)^{2} \\ & =\beta \mathcal{E}_{n}^{0}(a)+\frac{K}{2} \int_{a}^{L}(2 \pi r \mathrm{~d} r)\left(\frac{n}{r}\right)^{2}=\beta \mathcal{E}_{n}^{0}(a)+\pi K n^{2} \ln \left(\frac{L}{a}\right) . \tag{8.45} \end{align*}βEn​​=βEn0​(a)+2K​∫a​ d2x(∇θ)2=βEn0​(a)+2K​∫aL​(2πr dr)(rn​)2=βEn0​(a)+πKn2ln(aL​).​(8.45)​

The dominant part of the energy comes from the region outside the core, and diverges with the size of the system, LLL. The large energy cost of defects prevents their spontaneous formation close to zero temperature. The partition function for a configuration with a single vortex is

Z1(n)≈(La)2exp⁡[−βEn0(a)−πKn2ln⁡(La)]=yn0(a)(La)2−πKn2,\begin{equation*} Z_{1}(n) \approx\left(\frac{L}{a}\right)^{2} \exp \left[-\beta \mathcal{E}_{n}^{0}(a)-\pi K n^{2} \ln \left(\frac{L}{a}\right)\right]=y_{n}^{0}(a)\left(\frac{L}{a}\right)^{2-\pi K n^{2}}, \tag{8.46} \end{equation*}Z1​(n)≈(aL​)2exp[−βEn0​(a)−πKn2ln(aL​)]=yn0​(a)(aL​)2−πKn2,​(8.46)​

where (L/a)2(L / a)^{2}(L/a)2 results from the configurational entropy of possible vortex locations in a domain of area L2L^{2}L2. The entropy and energy of a vortex both grow as ln⁡L\ln LlnL, and the free energy is dominated by one or the other. At low temperatures (large KKK ) energy dominates and Z1Z_{1}Z1​, a measure of the weight of configurations with a single vortex, vanishes. At high enough temperatures, K<Kn=2/(πn2)K<K_{n}=2 /\left(\pi n^{2}\right)K<Kn​=2/(πn2), the entropy contribution is large enough to favor spontaneous formation of vortices. On increasing temperature, the first vortices to appear correspond to n=±1n= \pm 1n=±1 at Kc=2/πK_{c}=2 / \piKc​=2/π. Beyond this point there are many vortices in the system, and Eq. (8.46) is no longer useful.

The coupling Kc=2/πK_{c}=2 / \piKc​=2/π is a lower bound for the stability of the system to topological defects. This is because pairs (dipoles) of defects may appear at larger couplings. Consider a pair of charges ±1\pm 1±1 at a separation ddd. The distortions far away from the dipole center, r≫dr \gg dr≫d, can be obtained by superposing those of the individual vortices, and

∇θ=∇θ++∇θ−≈d⃗⋅∇(r^×z^r),\begin{equation*} \nabla \theta=\nabla \theta_{+}+\nabla \theta_{-} \approx \vec{d} \cdot \nabla\left(\frac{\widehat{r} \times \widehat{z}}{r}\right), \tag{8.47} \end{equation*}∇θ=∇θ+​+∇θ−​≈d⋅∇(rr×z​),​(8.47)​

decays as d/r2d / r^{2}d/r2. Integrating this distortion leads to a finite energy, and hence dipoles appear with the appropriate Boltzmann weight at any temperature. The low-temperature phase should thus be visualized as a gas of tightly bound dipoles. The number (and size) of dipoles increases with temperature, and the high-temperature state is a plasma of unbound vortices. The distinction between the two regimes can be studied by examining a typical net topological charge, Q(ℓ)Q(\ell)Q(ℓ), in a large area of dimension ℓ≫a\ell \gg aℓ≫a. The average charge is always zero, while fluctuations in the low-temperature phase are due to the dipoles straddling the perimeter, i.e. ⟨Q(ℓ)2⟩∝ℓ\left\langle Q(\ell)^{2}\right\rangle \propto \ell⟨Q(ℓ)2⟩∝ℓ. In the high-temperature state, charges of either sign can appear without restriction and ⟨Q(ℓ)2⟩∝ℓ2\left\langle Q(\ell)^{2}\right\rangle \propto \ell^{2}⟨Q(ℓ)2⟩∝ℓ2. (Note the similarity to the distinct behaviors of the Wilson loop in the high and low temperature phases of the Z2Z_{2}Z2​ gauge theory.)

To describe the transition between the two regimes, we need to properly account for the interactions between vortices. The distortion field u⃗≡∇θ\vec{u} \equiv \nabla \thetau≡∇θ, in the presence of a collection of vortices, is similar to the velocity of a fluid. In the absence of vorticity, the flow is potential, i.e. u⃗=u⃗0=∇ϕ\vec{u}=\vec{u}_{0}=\nabla \phiu=u0​=∇ϕ, and ∇×u⃗0=0\nabla \times \vec{u}_{0}=0∇×u0​=0. The topological charge can be related to ∇×u⃗\nabla \times \vec{u}∇×u by noting that for any closed path,

∮u⃗⋅ ds⃗=∫(d2xz^)⋅∇×u⃗,\begin{equation*} \oint \vec{u} \cdot \mathrm{~d} \vec{s}=\int\left(\mathrm{d}^{2} \mathbf{x} \widehat{z}\right) \cdot \nabla \times \vec{u}, \tag{8.48} \end{equation*}∮u⋅ ds=∫(d2xz)⋅∇×u,​(8.48)​

where the second integral is over the area enclosed by the path. Since the left-hand side is an integer multiple of 2π2 \pi2π, we can set

∇×u⃗=2πz^∑iniδ2(x−xi),\begin{equation*} \nabla \times \vec{u}=2 \pi \widehat{z} \sum_{i} n_{i} \delta^{2}\left(\mathbf{x}-\mathbf{x}_{i}\right), \tag{8.49} \end{equation*}∇×u=2πzi∑​ni​δ2(x−xi​),​(8.49)​

describing a collection of vortices of charge {ni}\left\{n_{i}\right\}{ni​} at locations {xi}\left\{\mathbf{x}_{i}\right\}{xi​}. The solution to Eq. (8.49) can be obtained by setting u⃗=u⃗0−∇×(z^ψ)\vec{u}=\vec{u}_{0}-\nabla \times(\widehat{z} \psi)u=u0​−∇×(zψ), leading to

∇×u⃗=z^∇2ψ,⟹∇2ψ=2π∑iniδ2(x−xi)\begin{equation*} \nabla \times \vec{u}=\widehat{z} \nabla^{2} \psi, \quad \Longrightarrow \quad \nabla^{2} \psi=2 \pi \sum_{i} n_{i} \delta^{2}\left(\mathbf{x}-\mathbf{x}_{i}\right) \tag{8.50} \end{equation*}∇×u=z∇2ψ,⟹∇2ψ=2πi∑​ni​δ2(x−xi​)​(8.50)​

Thus ψ\psiψ behaves like the potential due to a set of charges {2πni}\left\{2 \pi n_{i}\right\}{2πni​}. The solution,

ψ(x)=∑iniln⁡(∣x−xi∣)\begin{equation*} \psi(\mathbf{x})=\sum_{i} n_{i} \ln \left(\left|\mathbf{x}-\mathbf{x}_{i}\right|\right) \tag{8.51} \end{equation*}ψ(x)=i∑​ni​ln(∣x−xi​∣)​(8.51)​

is simply a superposition of the potentials as in Eq. (8.44). Any two dimensional distortion can thus be written as

u⃗=u⃗0+u⃗1=∇ϕ−∇×(z^ψ)\begin{equation*} \vec{u}=\vec{u}_{0}+\vec{u}_{1}=\nabla \phi-\nabla \times(\widehat{z} \psi) \tag{8.52} \end{equation*}u=u0​+u1​=∇ϕ−∇×(zψ)​(8.52)​

and the corresponding "kinetic energy", βH=K∫ d2x∣u⃗∣2/2\beta \mathcal{H}=K \int \mathrm{~d}^{2} \mathbf{x}|\vec{u}|^{2} / 2βH=K∫ d2x∣u∣2/2, decomposed as

βH=∫d2x[(∇ϕ)2−2∇ϕ⋅∇×(z^ψ)+(∇×z^ψ)2]\begin{equation*} \beta \mathcal{H}=\int \mathrm{d}^{2} \mathbf{x}\left[(\nabla \phi)^{2}-2 \nabla \phi \cdot \nabla \times(\widehat{z} \psi)+(\nabla \times \widehat{z} \psi)^{2}\right] \tag{8.53} \end{equation*}βH=∫d2x[(∇ϕ)2−2∇ϕ⋅∇×(zψ)+(∇×zψ)2]​(8.53)​

The second term vanishes, since following an integration by parts,

−∫d2x∇ϕ⋅∇×(z^ψ)=∫d2xϕ∇⋅(∇×z^ψ)\begin{equation*} -\int \mathrm{d}^{2} \mathbf{x} \nabla \phi \cdot \nabla \times(\widehat{z} \psi)=\int \mathrm{d}^{2} \mathbf{x} \phi \nabla \cdot(\nabla \times \widehat{z} \psi) \tag{8.54} \end{equation*}−∫d2x∇ϕ⋅∇×(zψ)=∫d2xϕ∇⋅(∇×zψ)​(8.54)​

and ∇⋅∇×u⃗=0\nabla \cdot \nabla \times \vec{u}=0∇⋅∇×u=0 for any vector. The third term in Eq. (8.53) can be simplified by noting that ∇ψ=(∂xψ,∂yψ,0)\nabla \psi=\left(\partial_{x} \psi, \partial_{y} \psi, 0\right)∇ψ=(∂x​ψ,∂y​ψ,0) and ∇×(z^ψ)=(−∂yψ,∂xψ,0)\nabla \times(\widehat{z} \psi)=\left(-\partial_{y} \psi, \partial_{x} \psi, 0\right)∇×(zψ)=(−∂y​ψ,∂x​ψ,0) are orthogonal vectors of equal length. Hence

βH1≡K2∫ d2x(∇×z^ψ)2=K2∫ d2x(∇ψ)2=−K2∫ d2xψ∇2ψ\begin{equation*} \beta \mathcal{H}_{1} \equiv \frac{K}{2} \int \mathrm{~d}^{2} \mathbf{x}(\nabla \times \widehat{z} \psi)^{2}=\frac{K}{2} \int \mathrm{~d}^{2} \mathbf{x}(\nabla \psi)^{2}=-\frac{K}{2} \int \mathrm{~d}^{2} \mathbf{x} \psi \nabla^{2} \psi \tag{8.55} \end{equation*}βH1​≡2K​∫ d2x(∇×zψ)2=2K​∫ d2x(∇ψ)2=−2K​∫ d2xψ∇2ψ​(8.55)​

where the second identity follows an integration by parts. Equations (8.50) and (8.51) now result in

βH1=−K2∫ d2x(∑iniln⁡(∣x−xi∣))(2π∑jnjδ2(x−xj))=−2π2K∑i,jninjC(xi−xj)\begin{align*} \beta \mathcal{H}_{1} & =-\frac{K}{2} \int \mathrm{~d}^{2} \mathbf{x}\left(\sum_{i} n_{i} \ln \left(\left|\mathbf{x}-\mathbf{x}_{i}\right|\right)\right)\left(2 \pi \sum_{j} n_{j} \delta^{2}\left(\mathbf{x}-\mathbf{x}_{j}\right)\right) \tag{8.56}\\ & =-2 \pi^{2} K \sum_{i, j} n_{i} n_{j} C\left(\mathbf{x}_{i}-\mathbf{x}_{j}\right) \end{align*}βH1​​=−2K​∫ d2x(i∑​ni​ln(∣x−xi​∣))(2πj∑​nj​δ2(x−xj​))=−2π2Ki,j∑​ni​nj​C(xi​−xj​)​(8.56)​

where C(x)=ln⁡(∣x∣)/2πC(\mathbf{x})=\ln (|\mathbf{x}|) / 2 \piC(x)=ln(∣x∣)/2π is the two-dimensional Coulomb potential. There is a difficulty with the above result for i=ji=ji=j due to the divergence of the logarithm at small arguments. This is a consequence of the breakdown of the continuum treatment at short distances. The self-interaction of a vortex is simply its core energy βEn0\beta \mathcal{E}_{n}^{0}βEn0​, and

βH1=∑iβEni0−4π2K∑i<jninjC(xi−xj).\begin{equation*} \beta \mathcal{H}_{1}=\sum_{i} \beta \mathcal{E}_{n_{i}}^{0}-4 \pi^{2} K \sum_{i<j} n_{i} n_{j} C\left(\mathbf{x}_{i}-\mathbf{x}_{j}\right) . \tag{8.57} \end{equation*}βH1​=i∑​βEni​0​−4π2Ki<j∑​ni​nj​C(xi​−xj​).​(8.57)​

The configuration space of the XY model close to zero temperature can thus be partitioned into different topological segments. The degrees of freedom in each segment are the charges {ni}\left\{n_{i}\right\}{ni​}, and locations {xi}\left\{\mathbf{x}_{i}\right\}{xi​}, of the vortices, in addition to the field ϕ(x)\phi(\mathbf{x})ϕ(x) describing spin waves. The partition function of the model can thus be approximated as

Z=∏i∫02π dθi2πexp⁡[K∑⟨i,j⟩cos⁡(θi−θj)]∝∫Dϕ(x)e−K2∫ d2x(∇ϕ)2∑{ni}∫d2xie−∑iβEni0+4π2K∑i<jninjC(xi−xj)≡Zs. w.ZQ\begin{align*} Z & =\prod_{i} \int_{0}^{2 \pi} \frac{\mathrm{~d} \theta_{i}}{2 \pi} \exp \left[K \sum_{\langle i, j\rangle} \cos \left(\theta_{i}-\theta_{j}\right)\right] \\ & \propto \int \mathcal{D} \phi(\mathbf{x}) \mathrm{e}^{-\frac{K}{2} \int \mathrm{~d}^{2} \mathbf{x}(\nabla \phi)^{2}} \sum_{\left\{n_{i}\right\}} \int \mathrm{d}^{2} \mathbf{x}_{i} \mathrm{e}^{-\sum_{i} \beta \mathcal{E}_{n_{i}}^{0}+4 \pi^{2} K \sum_{i<j} n_{i} n_{j} C\left(\mathbf{x}_{i}-\mathbf{x}_{j}\right)} \tag{8.58}\\ & \equiv Z_{\text {s. } \mathrm{w} .} Z_{Q} \end{align*}Z​=i∏​∫02π​2π dθi​​exp​K⟨i,j⟩∑​cos(θi​−θj​)​∝∫Dϕ(x)e−2K​∫ d2x(∇ϕ)2{ni​}∑​∫d2xi​e−∑i​βEni​0​+4π2K∑i<j​ni​nj​C(xi​−xj​)≡Zs. w.​ZQ​​(8.58)​

where Zs.w. Z_{\text {s.w. }}Zs.w. ​ is the Gaussian partition function of spin waves, and ZQZ_{Q}ZQ​ is the contribution of vortices. The latter describes a grand canonical gas of charged particles, interacting via the two dimensional Coulomb interaction. In calculating the Hamiltonian βH1\beta \mathcal{H}_{1}βH1​ in Eq. (8.55), we performed an integration by parts. The surface integral that was ignored in the process in fact grows with system size as (∑ini)ln⁡L\left(\sum_{i} n_{i}\right) \ln L(∑i​ni​)lnL. Thus only configurations that are overall neutral are included in calculating ZQZ_{Q}ZQ​. We further simplify the problem by considering only the elementary excitations with ni=±1n_{i}= \pm 1ni​=±1, which are most likely at low temperatures due to their lower energy. Setting y0≡exp⁡[−βE±10]y_{0} \equiv \exp \left[-\beta \mathcal{E}_{ \pm 1}^{0}\right]y0​≡exp[−βE±10​],

ZQ=∑N=0∞y0N∫∏i=1N d2xiexp⁡[4π2K∑i<jqiqjC(xi−xj)],\begin{equation*} Z_{Q}=\sum_{N=0}^{\infty} y_{0}^{N} \int \prod_{i=1}^{N} \mathrm{~d}^{2} \mathbf{x}_{i} \exp \left[4 \pi^{2} K \sum_{i<j} q_{i} q_{j} C\left(\mathbf{x}_{i}-\mathbf{x}_{j}\right)\right], \tag{8.59} \end{equation*}ZQ​=N=0∑∞​y0N​∫i=1∏N​ d2xi​exp[4π2Ki<j∑​qi​qj​C(xi​−xj​)],​(8.59)​

where qi=±1q_{i}= \pm 1qi​=±1, and ∑iqi=0\sum_{i} q_{i}=0∑i​qi​=0.

8.3 Renormalization group for the Coulomb gas

The two partition functions in Eq. (8.58) are independent and can be calculated separately. As the Gaussian partition function is analytic, any phase transitions of the XY model must originate in the Coulomb gas. As briefly discussed earlier, in the low temperature phase the charges appear only in a small population of tightly bound dipole pairs. The dipoles dissociate in the high temperature phase, forming a plasma. The two phases can be distinguished by examining the interaction between two external test charges at a large separation XXX. In the absence of any internal charges (for y0=0y_{0}=0y0​=0 ) in the medium, the two particles interact by the bare Coulomb interaction C(X)C(X)C(X). A finite density of internal charges for small y0y_{0}y0​ partially screens the external charges, and reduces the interaction between the test charges to C(X)/εC(X) / \varepsilonC(X)/ε, where ε\varepsilonε is an effective dielectric constant. There is an insulator to metal transition at sufficiently large y0y_{0}y0​. In the metallic (plasma) phase, the external charges are completely screened and their effective interaction decays exponentially.

To quantify this picture, we shall compute the effective interaction between two external charges at x\mathbf{x}x and x′\mathbf{x}^{\prime}x′, perturbatively in the fugacity y0y_{0}y0​. To lowest order, we need to include configurations with two internal charges (at y\mathbf{y}y and y′\mathbf{y}^{\prime}y′ ), and

e−βV(x−x′)=e−4π2KC(x−x′)×[1+y02∫ d2yd2y′e−4π2KC(y−y′)+4π2K[C(x−y)−C(x−y′)−C(y′−x)+C(x′−y′)]+O(y04)][1+y02∫ d2yd d2y′e−4π2KC(y−y′)+O(y04)]=e−4π2KC(x−x′)[1+y02∫ d2y d2y′e−4π2KC(y−y′)(e4π2KD(x,x′;y,y′)−1)+O(y04)],\begin{align*} \mathrm{e}^{-\beta \mathcal{V}\left(\mathbf{x}-\mathbf{x}^{\prime}\right)}= & \mathrm{e}^{-4 \pi^{2} K C\left(\mathbf{x}-\mathbf{x}^{\prime}\right)} \\ & \times \frac{\left[1+y_{0}^{2} \int \mathrm{~d}^{2} \mathbf{y} \mathbf{d}^{2} \mathbf{y}^{\prime} \mathrm{e}^{-4 \pi^{2} K C\left(\mathbf{y}-\mathbf{y}^{\prime}\right)+4 \pi^{2} K\left[C(\mathbf{x}-\mathbf{y})-C\left(\mathbf{x}-\mathbf{y}^{\prime}\right)-C\left(\mathbf{y}^{\prime}-\mathbf{x}\right)+C\left(\mathbf{x}^{\prime}-\mathbf{y}^{\prime}\right)\right]}+\mathcal{O}\left(y_{0}^{4}\right)\right]}{\left[1+y_{0}^{2} \int \mathrm{~d}^{2} \mathbf{y d} \mathrm{~d}^{2} \mathbf{y}^{\prime} \mathrm{e}^{-4 \pi^{2} K C\left(\mathbf{y}-\mathbf{y}^{\prime}\right)}+\mathcal{O}\left(y_{0}^{4}\right)\right]} \tag{8.60}\\ = & \mathrm{e}^{-4 \pi^{2} K C\left(\mathbf{x}-\mathbf{x}^{\prime}\right)}\left[1+y_{0}^{2} \int \mathrm{~d}^{2} \mathbf{y} \mathrm{~d}^{2} \mathbf{y}^{\prime} \mathrm{e}^{-4 \pi^{2} K C\left(\mathbf{y}-\mathbf{y}^{\prime}\right)}\left(\mathrm{e}^{4 \pi^{2} K D\left(\mathbf{x}, \mathbf{x}^{\prime} ; \mathbf{y}, \mathbf{y}^{\prime}\right)}-1\right)+\mathcal{O}\left(y_{0}^{4}\right)\right], \end{align*}e−βV(x−x′)==​e−4π2KC(x−x′)×[1+y02​∫ d2yd d2y′e−4π2KC(y−y′)+O(y04​)][1+y02​∫ d2yd2y′e−4π2KC(y−y′)+4π2K[C(x−y)−C(x−y′)−C(y′−x)+C(x′−y′)]+O(y04​)]​e−4π2KC(x−x′)[1+y02​∫ d2y d2y′e−4π2KC(y−y′)(e4π2KD(x,x′;y,y′)−1)+O(y04​)],​(8.60)​

where D(x,x′;y,y′)D\left(\mathbf{x}, \mathbf{x}^{\prime} ; \mathbf{y}, \mathbf{y}^{\prime}\right)D(x,x′;y,y′) is the interaction between the internal and external dipoles. The direct interaction between internal charges tends to keep the separation r=y′−y\mathbf{r}=\mathbf{y}^{\prime}-\mathbf{y}r=y′−y small. Using the center of mass R=(y+y′)/2\mathbf{R}=\left(\mathbf{y}+\mathbf{y}^{\prime}\right) / 2R=(y+y′)/2, we can change variables to y=R−r/2\mathbf{y}=\mathbf{R}-\mathbf{r} / 2y=R−r/2 and y′=R+r/2\mathbf{y}^{\prime}=\mathbf{R}+\mathbf{r} / 2y′=R+r/2, and expand the dipole-dipole interaction for small r\mathbf{r}r as

D(x,x′;y,y′)=C(x−R+r2)−C(x−R−r2)−C(x′−R+r2)+C(x′−R−r2)=−r⋅∇RC(x−R)+r⋅∇RC(x′−R)+O(r3).\begin{align*} D\left(\mathbf{x}, \mathbf{x}^{\prime} ; \mathbf{y}, \mathbf{y}^{\prime}\right) & =C\left(\mathbf{x}-\mathbf{R}+\frac{\mathbf{r}}{2}\right)-C\left(\mathbf{x}-\mathbf{R}-\frac{\mathbf{r}}{2}\right)-C\left(\mathbf{x}^{\prime}-\mathbf{R}+\frac{\mathbf{r}}{2}\right)+C\left(\mathbf{x}^{\prime}-\mathbf{R}-\frac{\mathbf{r}}{2}\right) \\ & =-\mathbf{r} \cdot \nabla_{\mathbf{R}} C(\mathbf{x}-\mathbf{R})+\mathbf{r} \cdot \nabla_{\mathbf{R}} C\left(\mathbf{x}^{\prime}-\mathbf{R}\right)+\mathcal{O}\left(r^{3}\right) . \tag{8.61} \end{align*}D(x,x′;y,y′)​=C(x−R+2r​)−C(x−R−2r​)−C(x′−R+2r​)+C(x′−R−2r​)=−r⋅∇R​C(x−R)+r⋅∇R​C(x′−R)+O(r3).​(8.61)​

To the same order

e4π2KD(x,x′,y,y′)−1=−4π2Kr⋅∇R(C(x−R)−C(x′−R))+8π4K2[r⋅∇R(C(x−R)−C(x′−R))]2+O(r3)\begin{align*} \mathrm{e}^{4 \pi^{2} K D\left(\mathbf{x}, \mathbf{x}^{\prime}, \mathbf{y}, \mathbf{y}^{\prime}\right)}-1= & -4 \pi^{2} K \mathbf{r} \cdot \nabla_{\mathbf{R}}\left(C(\mathbf{x}-\mathbf{R})-C\left(\mathbf{x}^{\prime}-\mathbf{R}\right)\right) \\ & +8 \pi^{4} K^{2}\left[\mathbf{r} \cdot \nabla_{\mathbf{R}}\left(C(\mathbf{x}-\mathbf{R})-C\left(\mathbf{x}^{\prime}-\mathbf{R}\right)\right)\right]^{2}+\mathcal{O}\left(r^{3}\right) \tag{8.62} \end{align*}e4π2KD(x,x′,y,y′)−1=​−4π2Kr⋅∇R​(C(x−R)−C(x′−R))+8π4K2[r⋅∇R​(C(x−R)−C(x′−R))]2+O(r3)​(8.62)​

After the change of variables ∫d2yd2y′→∫d2r d2R\int \mathrm{d}^{2} \mathbf{y d}^{2} \mathbf{y}^{\prime} \rightarrow \int \mathrm{d}^{2} \mathbf{r} \mathrm{~d}^{2} \mathbf{R}∫d2yd2y′→∫d2r d2R, the effective interaction becomes

e−βV(x−x′)=e−4π2KC(x−x′){[1+y02∫ d2r d2Re−4π2KC(r)×(−4π2Kr⋅∇R(C(x−R)−C(x′−R))+8π4K2[r⋅∇R(C(x−R)−C(x′−R))]2+O(r3))+O(y04)]}\begin{align*} \mathrm{e}^{-\beta \mathcal{V}\left(\mathbf{x}-\mathbf{x}^{\prime}\right)}= & \mathrm{e}^{-4 \pi^{2} K C\left(\mathbf{x}-\mathbf{x}^{\prime}\right)}\left\{\left[1+y_{0}^{2} \int \mathrm{~d}^{2} \mathbf{r} \mathrm{~d}^{2} \mathbf{R} \mathrm{e}^{-4 \pi^{2} K C(\mathbf{r})}\right.\right. \\ & \times\left(-4 \pi^{2} K \mathbf{r} \cdot \nabla_{\mathbf{R}}\left(C(\mathbf{x}-\mathbf{R})-C\left(\mathbf{x}^{\prime}-\mathbf{R}\right)\right)\right. \tag{8.63}\\ & \left.\left.\left.+8 \pi^{4} K^{2}\left[\mathbf{r} \cdot \nabla_{\mathbf{R}}\left(C(\mathbf{x}-\mathbf{R})-C\left(\mathbf{x}^{\prime}-\mathbf{R}\right)\right)\right]^{2}+\mathcal{O}\left(r^{3}\right)\right)+\mathcal{O}\left(y_{0}^{4}\right)\right]\right\} \end{align*}e−βV(x−x′)=​e−4π2KC(x−x′){[1+y02​∫ d2r d2Re−4π2KC(r)×(−4π2Kr⋅∇R​(C(x−R)−C(x′−R))+8π4K2[r⋅∇R​(C(x−R)−C(x′−R))]2+O(r3))+O(y04​)]}​(8.63)​

Following the angular integrations in d2r\mathrm{d}^{2} \mathbf{r}d2r, the term linear in r\mathbf{r}r vanishes, while the angular average of (r⋅∇RC)2\left(\mathbf{r} \cdot \nabla_{\mathbf{R}} C\right)^{2}(r⋅∇R​C)2 is r2∣∇RC∣2/2r^{2}\left|\nabla_{\mathbf{R}} C\right|^{2} / 2r2∣∇R​C∣2/2. Hence Eq. (8.63) simplifies to

e−βV(x−x′)=e−4π2KC(x−x′)×[1+y02∫(2πr dr)e−4π2KC(r)8π4K2r22∫d2R(∇R(C(x−R)−C(x′−R)))2+O(r4)]\begin{align*} \mathrm{e}^{-\beta \mathcal{V}\left(\mathbf{x}-\mathbf{x}^{\prime}\right)}= & \mathrm{e}^{-4 \pi^{2} K C\left(\mathbf{x}-\mathbf{x}^{\prime}\right)} \\ & \times\left[1+y_{0}^{2} \int(2 \pi r \mathrm{~d} r) \mathrm{e}^{-4 \pi^{2} K C(r)} 8 \pi^{4} K^{2} \frac{r^{2}}{2}\right. \tag{8.64}\\ & \left.\int \mathrm{d}^{2} \mathbf{R}\left(\nabla_{\mathbf{R}}\left(C(\mathbf{x}-\mathbf{R})-C\left(\mathbf{x}^{\prime}-\mathbf{R}\right)\right)\right)^{2}+\mathcal{O}\left(r^{4}\right)\right] \end{align*}e−βV(x−x′)=​e−4π2KC(x−x′)×[1+y02​∫(2πr dr)e−4π2KC(r)8π4K22r2​∫d2R(∇R​(C(x−R)−C(x′−R)))2+O(r4)]​(8.64)​

The remaining integral can be evaluated by parts,

∫d2R[∇R(C(x−R)−C(x′−R))]2=−∫d2R(C(x−R)−C(x′−R))(∇2C(x−R)−∇2C(x′−R))=−∫d2R(C(x−R)−C(x′−R))(δ2(x−R)−δ2(x′−R))=2C(x−x′)−2C(0).\begin{align*} & \int \mathrm{d}^{2} \mathbf{R}\left[\nabla_{\mathbf{R}}\left(C(\mathbf{x}-\mathbf{R})-C\left(\mathbf{x}^{\prime}-\mathbf{R}\right)\right)\right]^{2} \\ = & -\int \mathrm{d}^{2} \mathbf{R}\left(C(\mathbf{x}-\mathbf{R})-C\left(\mathbf{x}^{\prime}-\mathbf{R}\right)\right)\left(\nabla^{2} C(\mathbf{x}-\mathbf{R})-\nabla^{2} C\left(\mathbf{x}^{\prime}-\mathbf{R}\right)\right) \tag{8.65}\\ = & -\int \mathrm{d}^{2} \mathbf{R}\left(C(\mathbf{x}-\mathbf{R})-C\left(\mathbf{x}^{\prime}-\mathbf{R}\right)\right)\left(\delta^{2}(\mathbf{x}-\mathbf{R})-\delta^{2}\left(\mathbf{x}^{\prime}-\mathbf{R}\right)\right) \\ = & 2 C\left(\mathbf{x}-\mathbf{x}^{\prime}\right)-2 C(0) . \end{align*}===​∫d2R[∇R​(C(x−R)−C(x′−R))]2−∫d2R(C(x−R)−C(x′−R))(∇2C(x−R)−∇2C(x′−R))−∫d2R(C(x−R)−C(x′−R))(δ2(x−R)−δ2(x′−R))2C(x−x′)−2C(0).​(8.65)​

The short distance divergence can again be absorbed into a proper cutoff with C(x)→ln⁡(x/a)/2πC(x) \rightarrow \ln (x / a) / 2 \piC(x)→ln(x/a)/2π, and

e−βV(x−x′)=e−4π2KC(x−x′)[1+16π5K2y02C(x−x′)∫drr3e−2πKln⁡(r/a)+O(y04)]\begin{equation*} \mathrm{e}^{-\beta \mathcal{V}\left(\mathbf{x}-\mathbf{x}^{\prime}\right)}=\mathrm{e}^{-4 \pi^{2} K C\left(\mathbf{x}-\mathbf{x}^{\prime}\right)}\left[1+16 \pi^{5} K^{2} y_{0}^{2} C\left(\mathbf{x}-\mathbf{x}^{\prime}\right) \int \mathrm{d} r r^{3} \mathrm{e}^{-2 \pi K \ln (r / a)}+\mathcal{O}\left(y_{0}^{4}\right)\right] \tag{8.66} \end{equation*}e−βV(x−x′)=e−4π2KC(x−x′)[1+16π5K2y02​C(x−x′)∫drr3e−2πKln(r/a)+O(y04​)]​(8.66)​

The second order term can be exponentiated to give an effective interaction βV(x−x′)≡4π2Keff C(x−x′)\beta \mathcal{V}\left(\mathbf{x}-\mathbf{x}^{\prime}\right) \equiv 4 \pi^{2} K_{\text {eff }} C\left(\mathbf{x}-\mathbf{x}^{\prime}\right)βV(x−x′)≡4π2Keff ​C(x−x′), with

Keff=K−4π3K2y02a2πK∫a∞drr3−2πK+O(y04)\begin{equation*} K_{\mathrm{eff}}=K-4 \pi^{3} K^{2} y_{0}^{2} a^{2 \pi K} \int_{a}^{\infty} \mathrm{d} r r^{3-2 \pi K}+\mathcal{O}\left(y_{0}^{4}\right) \tag{8.67} \end{equation*}Keff​=K−4π3K2y02​a2πK∫a∞​drr3−2πK+O(y04​)​(8.67)​

We have thus evaluated the dielectric constant of the medium, ε=K/Keff \varepsilon=K / K_{\text {eff }}ε=K/Keff ​, perturbatively to order of y02y_{0}^{2}y02​. However, the perturbative correction is small only as long as the integral in rrr converges at large rrr. The breakdown of the perturbation theory for K<Kc=2/πK<K_{c}=2 / \piK<Kc​=2/π, occurs precisely at the point where the free energy of an isolated vortex changes sign. This breakdown of perturbation theory is reminiscent of that encountered in the Landau-Ginzburg model for d<4d<4d<4. Using the experience gained from that problem, we shall reorganize the perturbation series into a renormalization group for the parameters KKK and y0y_{0}y0​.

To construct an RG for the Coulomb gas, note that the partition function for the system in Eq. (8.59) involves two parameters ( K,y0K, y_{0}K,y0​ ), and has an implicit cutoff aaa, related to the minimum separation between vortices. As discussed earlier, the distinction between regions inside and outside the core of a vortex is arbitrary. Increasing the core size to bab aba modifies not only the core energy, hence y0y_{0}y0​, but also the interaction parameter KKK. The latter is a consequence of the change in the dielectric properties of the medium due to dipoles of separations between aaa and bab aba. The change in fugacity is obtained from Eq. (8.46) by changing aaa to bab aba as

y~0(ba)=b2−πKy0(a)\begin{equation*} \widetilde{y}_{0}(b a)=b^{2-\pi K} y_{0}(a) \tag{8.68} \end{equation*}y​0​(ba)=b2−πKy0​(a)​(8.68)​

The modified Coulomb interaction due to dipoles of all sizes is given in Eq. (8.67). (The perturbative calculation at order of y02y_{0}^{2}y02​ incorporates only dipoles.) From dipoles in the size range aaa to bab aba, we obtain a contribution

K~=K[1−(2π2K)∫aba(2πr dr)(y02e−4π2KC(r))r2]\begin{equation*} \widetilde{K}=K\left[1-\left(2 \pi^{2} K\right) \int_{a}^{b a}(2 \pi r \mathrm{~d} r)\left(y_{0}^{2} \mathrm{e}^{-4 \pi^{2} K C(r)}\right) r^{2}\right] \tag{8.69} \end{equation*}K=K[1−(2π2K)∫aba​(2πr dr)(y02​e−4π2KC(r))r2]​(8.69)​

where the terms are grouped so as to make the similarity to standard computations of the dielectric constant apparent. (The probability of creating a dipole of size rrr is multiplied by its polarizability; the role of β=(kBT)−1\beta=\left(k_{B} T\right)^{-1}β=(kB​T)−1 is played by 2π2K2 \pi^{2} K2π2K.)

By choosing an infinitesimal b=eℓ≈1+ℓb=e^{\ell} \approx 1+\ellb=eℓ≈1+ℓ, Eq. (8.69) is converted to

dK dℓ=−4π3K2a4y02+O(y04)\begin{equation*} \frac{\mathrm{d} K}{\mathrm{~d} \ell}=-4 \pi^{3} K^{2} a^{4} y_{0}^{2}+\mathcal{O}\left(y_{0}^{4}\right) \tag{8.70} \end{equation*} dℓdK​=−4π3K2a4y02​+O(y04​)​(8.70)​

Including the fugacity, the recursion relations are

{dK−1 dℓ=4π3a4y02+O(y04)dy0 dℓ=(2−πK)y0+O(y03)(8.71)\left\{\begin{array}{l} \frac{\mathrm{d} K^{-1}}{\mathrm{~d} \ell}=4 \pi^{3} a^{4} y_{0}^{2}+\mathcal{O}\left(y_{0}^{4}\right) \tag{8.71}\\ \frac{\mathrm{d} y_{0}}{\mathrm{~d} \ell}=(2-\pi K) y_{0}+\mathcal{O}\left(y_{0}^{3}\right) \end{array}\right.{ dℓdK−1​=4π3a4y02​+O(y04​) dℓdy0​​=(2−πK)y0​+O(y03​)​(8.71)

originally obtained by Kosterlitz [J. Phys. C 7, 1046 (1974)]. While dK−1/dℓ≥\mathrm{d} K^{-1} / \mathrm{d} \ell \geqdK−1/dℓ≥ 0 , the recursion relation for y0y_{0}y0​ changes sign at Kc−1=π/2K_{c}^{-1}=\pi / 2Kc−1​=π/2. At smaller values of K−1K^{-1}K−1 (high temperatures) y0y_{0}y0​ is relevant, while at lower temperatures it is irrelevant. Thus the RG flows separate the parameter space into two regions. At low temperatures and small y0y_{0}y0​, flows terminate on a fixed line at y0=0y_{0}=0y0​=0 and Keff ≥2/πK_{\text {eff }} \geq 2 / \piKeff ​≥2/π. This is the insulating phase in which only dipoles of finite size occur. (Hence the vanishing of y0y_{0}y0​ under coarse graining.) The strength of the effective Coulomb interaction is given by the point on the fixed line that the flows terminate on. Flows not terminating on the fixed line asymptote to larger values of K−1K^{-1}K−1 and y0y_{0}y0​, where perturbation theory breaks down. This is the signal of the high-temperature phase with an abundance of vortices.

Fig. 8.5 Renormalization group flows of the Coulomb gas system. The line of fixed points at y0=0y_{0}=0y0​=0 terminates at K−1=π/2K^{-1}=\pi / 2K−1=π/2 。

The critical trajectory that separates the two regions of the phase diagram flows to a fixed point at ( Kc−1=π/2,y0=0K_{c}^{-1}=\pi / 2, y_{0}=0Kc−1​=π/2,y0​=0 ). To find the critical behavior at the transition, expand the recursion relations in the vicinity of this point by setting x=K−1−π/2x=K^{-1}-\pi / 2x=K−1−π/2, and y=y0a2y=y_{0} a^{2}y=y0​a2. To lowest order, Eqs. (8.71) simplify to

{dx dℓ=4π3y2+O(xy2,y4)dy dℓ=4πxy+O(x2y,y3)(8.7)\left\{\begin{array}{l} \frac{\mathrm{d} x}{\mathrm{~d} \ell}=4 \pi^{3} y^{2}+\mathcal{O}\left(x y^{2}, y^{4}\right) \tag{8.7}\\ \frac{\mathrm{d} y}{\mathrm{~d} \ell}=\frac{4}{\pi} x y+\mathcal{O}\left(x^{2} y, y^{3}\right) \end{array}\right.{ dℓdx​=4π3y2+O(xy2,y4) dℓdy​=π4​xy+O(x2y,y3)​(8.7)

The recursion relations are inherently nonlinear in the vicinity of the fixed point. This is quite different from the linear recursion relations that we have encountered so far, and the resulting critical behavior is non-standard. First note that Eqs. (8.72) imply

dx2 dℓ=8π3y2x=π4 dy2 dℓ,⇒ d dℓ(x2−π4y2)=0,⇒x2−π4y2=c\begin{equation*} \frac{\mathrm{d} x^{2}}{\mathrm{~d} \ell}=8 \pi^{3} y^{2} x=\pi^{4} \frac{\mathrm{~d} y^{2}}{\mathrm{~d} \ell}, \quad \Rightarrow \quad \frac{\mathrm{~d}}{\mathrm{~d} \ell}\left(x^{2}-\pi^{4} y^{2}\right)=0, \quad \Rightarrow \quad x^{2}-\pi^{4} y^{2}=c \tag{8.73} \end{equation*} dℓdx2​=8π3y2x=π4 dℓ dy2​,⇒ dℓ d​(x2−π4y2)=0,⇒x2−π4y2=c​(8.73)​

The RG flows thus proceed along hyperbolas characterized by different values of ccc. For c>0c>0c>0, the focus of the hyperbola is along the yyy-axis, and the flows proceed to (x,y)→∞(x, y) \rightarrow \infty(x,y)→∞. The hyperbolas with c<0c<0c<0 have foci along the xxx axis, and have two branches in the half plane y≥0y \geq 0y≥0 : the trajectories for x<0x<0x<0 flow to the fixed line, while those in the x>0x>0x>0 quadrant flow to infinity. The critical trajectory separating flows to zero and infinite yyy corresponds to c=0c=0c=0, i.e. xc=−π2ycx_{c}=-\pi^{2} y_{c}xc​=−π2yc​. Therefore, a small but finite fugacity y0y_{0}y0​ reduces the critical temperature to Kc−1=π/2−π2y0a2+O(y02)K_{c}^{-1}=\pi / 2-\pi^{2} y_{0} a^{2}+\mathcal{O}\left(y_{0}^{2}\right)Kc−1​=π/2−π2y0​a2+O(y02​).

Fig. 8.6 Detailed views of the RG flows in the vicinity of the termination point of the line of low-temperature fixed points. The dashed line indicates a trajectory of the initial Hamiltonian as the temperature is varied. The phase transition occurs when this trajectory intersects the dotted line.

In terms of the original XY model, the low-temperature phase is characterized by a line of fixed points with Keff =lim⁡ℓ→∞K(ℓ)≥2/πK_{\text {eff }}=\lim _{\ell \rightarrow \infty} K(\ell) \geq 2 / \piKeff ​=limℓ→∞​K(ℓ)≥2/π. There is no correlation length at a fixed point, and indeed the correlations in this phase decay as a power law, ⟨cos⁡(θr−cos⁡θ0)⟩∼1/rη\left\langle\cos \left(\theta_{\mathbf{r}}-\cos \theta_{0}\right)\right\rangle \sim 1 / r^{\eta}⟨cos(θr​−cosθ0​)⟩∼1/rη, with η=1/(2πKeff )≤1/4\eta=1 /\left(2 \pi K_{\text {eff }}\right) \leq 1 / 4η=1/(2πKeff ​)≤1/4. Since the parameter ccc is negative in the low temperature phase, and vanishes at the critical point, we can set it to c=−b2(Tc−T)c=-b^{2}\left(T_{c}-T\right)c=−b2(Tc​−T) close to the transition. In other words, the trajectory of initial points tracks a line (x0(T),y0(T))\left(x_{0}(T), y_{0}(T)\right)(x0​(T),y0​(T)). The resulting c=x02−π4y02∝(Tc−T)c=x_{0}^{2}-\pi^{4} y_{0}^{2} \propto\left(T_{c}-T\right)c=x02​−π4y02​∝(Tc​−T) is a linear measure of the vicinity to the phase transition. Under renormalization, such trajectories flow to a fixed point at y=0y=0y=0, and x=−bTc−Tx=-b \sqrt{T_{c}-T}x=−bTc​−T​. Thus in the vicinity of transition, the effective interaction parameter

Keff =2π−4π2lim⁡ℓ→∞x(ℓ)=2π+4bπ2Tc−T\begin{equation*} K_{\text {eff }}=\frac{2}{\pi}-\frac{4}{\pi^{2}} \lim _{\ell \rightarrow \infty} x(\ell)=\frac{2}{\pi}+\frac{4 b}{\pi^{2}} \sqrt{T_{c}-T} \tag{8.74} \end{equation*}Keff ​=π2​−π24​ℓ→∞lim​x(ℓ)=π2​+π24b​Tc​−T​​(8.74)​

has a square root singularity. The stiffness Keff K_{\text {eff }}Keff ​, can be measured in experiments on superfluid films. In the superfluid phase, the order parameter is the condensate wavefunction ψ(x)=Ψeiθ\psi(\mathbf{x})=\Psi \mathrm{e}^{\mathrm{i} \theta}ψ(x)=Ψeiθ. Variations in the phase θ\thetaθ lead to a superfluid kinetic energy,

H=∫ddxψ∗(−ℏ2∇22m)ψ=ℏ2Ψ22m∫ ddx(∇θ)2\begin{equation*} \mathcal{H}=\int \mathrm{d}^{d} \mathbf{x} \psi^{*}\left(-\frac{\hbar^{2} \nabla^{2}}{2 m}\right) \psi=\frac{\hbar^{2} \Psi^{2}}{2 m} \int \mathrm{~d}^{d} \mathbf{x}(\nabla \theta)^{2} \tag{8.75} \end{equation*}H=∫ddxψ∗(−2mℏ2∇2​)ψ=2mℏ2Ψ2​∫ ddx(∇θ)2​(8.75)​

where mmm is the particle (helium 4) mass. The corresponding XY model has a stiffness K=ℏ2ρs/(2m2kBT)K=\hbar^{2} \rho_{s} /\left(2 m^{2} k_{\mathrm{B}} T\right)K=ℏ2ρs​/(2m2kB​T), where ρs=mΨ2\rho_{s}=m \Psi^{2}ρs​=mΨ2 is the superfluid mass density. The density ρs\rho_{s}ρs​ is measured by examining the changes in the inertia of a torsional oscillator; the superfluid fraction, mΨ2m \Psi^{2}mΨ2, experiences no friction and does not oscillate. Bishop and Reppy [Phys. Rev. Lett. 40, 1727 (1978)] examined ρs\rho_{s}ρs​ for a variety of superfluid films of different thickness wrapped around a torsional cylinder. They constructed the effective stiffness KKK as a function of temperature, and found that for all films it undergoes a universal jump of 2/π2 / \pi2/π at the transition. The behavior of KKK for T<TcT<T_{c}T<Tc​ was consistent with a square root singularity.

Correlations decay exponentially in the high-temperature phase. How does the correlation length ξ\xiξ diverge at TcT_{c}Tc​ ? The parameter c=x2−π4y2=b2(T−c=x^{2}-\pi^{4} y^{2}=b^{2}(T-c=x2−π4y2=b2(T− TcT_{c}Tc​ ) is now positive all along the hyperbolic trajectory. The recursion relation for xxx,

dx dℓ=4π3y2=4π(x2+b2(T−Tc)),\begin{equation*} \frac{\mathrm{d} x}{\mathrm{~d} \ell}=4 \pi^{3} y^{2}=\frac{4}{\pi}\left(x^{2}+b^{2}\left(T-T_{c}\right)\right), \tag{8.76} \end{equation*} dℓdx​=4π3y2=π4​(x2+b2(T−Tc​)),​(8.76)​

can be integrated to give

dxx2+b2(T−Tc)=4π dℓ,⟹1bT−Tcarctan⁡(xbT−Tc)=4πℓ.\begin{equation*} \frac{\mathrm{d} x}{x^{2}+b^{2}\left(T-T_{c}\right)}=\frac{4}{\pi} \mathrm{~d} \ell, \Longrightarrow \frac{1}{b \sqrt{T-T_{c}}} \arctan \left(\frac{x}{b \sqrt{T-T_{c}}}\right)=\frac{4}{\pi} \ell . \tag{8.77} \end{equation*}x2+b2(T−Tc​)dx​=π4​ dℓ,⟹bT−Tc​​1​arctan(bT−Tc​​x​)=π4​ℓ.​(8.77)​

The contribution of the initial point to the left-hand side of the above equation can be left out if x0∝(T−Tc)≪1x_{0} \propto\left(T-T_{c}\right) \ll 1x0​∝(T−Tc​)≪1. The integration has to be stopped when x(ℓ)∼y(ℓ)∼1x(\ell) \sim y(\ell) \sim 1x(ℓ)∼y(ℓ)∼1, since the perturbative calculation is no longer valid beyond this point. This occurs for a value of

ℓ∗≈π4bT−Tcπ2,\begin{equation*} \ell^{*} \approx \frac{\pi}{4 b \sqrt{T-T_{c}}} \frac{\pi}{2}, \tag{8.78} \end{equation*}ℓ∗≈4bT−Tc​​π​2π​,​(8.78)​

where we have used arctan⁡(1/bT−Tc)≈arctan⁡(∞)=π/2\arctan \left(1 / b \sqrt{T-T_{c}}\right) \approx \arctan (\infty)=\pi / 2arctan(1/bT−Tc​​)≈arctan(∞)=π/2. The resulting correlation length is

ξ≈aeℓ∗≈aexp⁡(π28bT−Tc)\begin{equation*} \xi \approx a \mathrm{e}^{\ell^{*}} \approx a \exp \left(\frac{\pi^{2}}{8 b \sqrt{T-T_{c}}}\right) \tag{8.79} \end{equation*}ξ≈aeℓ∗≈aexp(8bT−Tc​​π2​)​(8.79)​

Unlike any of the transitions encountered so far, the divergence of the correlation length is not through a power law. This is a consequence of the nonlinear nature of the recursion relations in the vicinity of the fixed point.

Vortices occur in bound pairs for distances smaller than ξ\xiξ, while there can be an excess of vortices of one sign or the other at larger separations. The interactions between vortices at large distances can be obtained from the Debye-Hückel theory of polyelectrolytes. According to this theory the free charges screen each other leading to a screened Coulomb interaction, exp⁡(−r/ξ)C(r)\exp (-r / \xi) C(r)exp(−r/ξ)C(r). On approaching the transition from the high-temperature side, the singular part of the free energy,

fsing ∝ξ−2∝exp⁡(−π24bT−Tc)\begin{equation*} f_{\text {sing }} \propto \xi^{-2} \propto \exp \left(-\frac{\pi^{2}}{4 b \sqrt{T-T_{c}}}\right) \tag{8.80} \end{equation*}fsing ​∝ξ−2∝exp(−4bT−Tc​​π2​)​(8.80)​

has only an essential singularity. All derivatives of this function are finite at TcT_{c}Tc​. Thus the predicted heat capacity is quite smooth at the transition. Numerical results based on the RG equations by Berker and Nelson [Phys. Rev. B 19, 2488 (1979)] indicate a smooth maximum in the heat capacity at a temperature higher than TcT_{c}Tc​, corresponding to the point at which the majority of dipoles unbind.

The Kosterlitz-Thouless picture of vortex unbinding has found numerous applications in two-dimensional systems such as superconducting and superfluid films, thin liquid crystals, Josephson junction arrays, electrons on the surface of helium films, etc. Perhaps more importantly, the general idea of topological defects has had much impact in understanding the behavior of many systems. The theory of two-dimensional melting developed in the next sections is one such example.

8.4 Two-dimensional solids

The transition from a liquid to solid involves the breaking of translational and orientational symmetry. Here we shall examine the types of order that are present in a two-dimensional solid. The destruction of such order upon melting is discussed next. (a) A low-temperature treatment of the problem starts with the perfect solid at T=0T=0T=0. The equilibrium configuration of atoms forms a lattice, r0(m,n)=me1+ne2\mathbf{r}_{0}(m, n)=m \mathbf{e}_{1}+n \mathbf{e}_{2}r0​(m,n)=me1​+ne2​, where e1\mathbf{e}_{1}e1​ and e2\mathbf{e}_{2}e2​ are basis vectors, and {m,n}\{m, n\}{m,n} are integers. At finite temperatures, the atoms fluctuate away from their equilibrium position, moving to

r(m,n)=r0(m,n)+u(m,n).\begin{equation*} \mathbf{r}(m, n)=\mathbf{r}_{0}(m, n)+\mathbf{u}(m, n) . \tag{8.81} \end{equation*}r(m,n)=r0​(m,n)+u(m,n).​(8.81)​

The low-temperature distortions do not vary substantially over nearby atoms, enabling us to define a coarse-grained distortion field u(x)\mathbf{u}(\mathbf{x})u(x), where x≡(x1,x2)\mathbf{x} \equiv\left(x_{1}, x_{2}\right)x≡(x1​,x2​) is treated as continuous, with an implicit short distance cutoff of the order of the lattice spacing aaa. The distortion u\mathbf{u}u is the analog of the angle θ\thetaθ in the XY model. (b) Due to translational symmetry, the energy depends only on the strain matrix,

uij(x)=12(∂iuj+∂jui),⟹uij(q)=i2(qiuj+qjui)\begin{equation*} u_{i j}(\mathbf{x})=\frac{1}{2}\left(\partial_{i} u_{j}+\partial_{j} u_{i}\right), \quad \Longrightarrow \quad u_{i j}(\mathbf{q})=\frac{\mathrm{i}}{2}\left(q_{i} u_{j}+q_{j} u_{i}\right) \tag{8.82} \end{equation*}uij​(x)=21​(∂i​uj​+∂j​ui​),⟹uij​(q)=2i​(qi​uj​+qj​ui​)​(8.82)​

The elastic energy must respect the symmetries of the underlying lattice. For simplicity, we shall consider the triangular lattice whose elastic energy is fully isotropic, i.e. invariant under all rotations (see Landau and Lifshitz, Theory of Elasticity, Pergamon Press). In terms of the Lamé coefficients λ\lambdaλ and μ\muμ,

βH=12∫ d2x[2μuijuij+λuiiujj]=12∫ d2q(2π)2[μq2u2+(μ+λ)(q⋅u)2]\begin{align*} \beta \mathcal{H} & =\frac{1}{2} \int \mathrm{~d}^{2} \mathbf{x}\left[2 \mu u_{i j} u_{i j}+\lambda u_{i i} u_{j j}\right] \\ & =\frac{1}{2} \int \frac{\mathrm{~d}^{2} \mathbf{q}}{(2 \pi)^{2}}\left[\mu q^{2} u^{2}+(\mu+\lambda)(\mathbf{q} \cdot \mathbf{u})^{2}\right] \tag{8.83} \end{align*}βH​=21​∫ d2x[2μuij​uij​+λuii​ujj​]=21​∫(2π)2 d2q​[μq2u2+(μ+λ)(q⋅u)2]​(8.83)​

The rotational invariance of energy is insured by the implicit sum over the indices (i,j)(i, j)(i,j) in the above expression. In the Fourier representation, the energy depends on the quantities q2,∣u∣2q^{2},|\mathbf{u}|^{2}q2,∣u∣2, and (q⋅u)2(\mathbf{q} \cdot \mathbf{u})^{2}(q⋅u)2 which are clearly independent of rotations. For other lattices, there are more elastic coefficients, since the energy need only be invariant under the subset of lattice rotations. For example, the symmetry of a square lattice permits a term proportional to (qx2ux2+qy2uy2)\left(q_{x}^{2} u_{x}^{2}+q_{y}^{2} u_{y}^{2}\right)(qx2​ux2​+qy2​uy2​). (c) The Goldstone modes associated with the broken translational symmetry are phonons, the normal modes of vibrations. Equation (8.83) supports two types of normal modes: (i) Transverse modes with q⊥u\mathbf{q} \perp \mathbf{u}q⊥u have energy

βHT=μ2∫ d2q(2π)2q2uT2,⟹⟨∣uT(q)∣2⟩=1μq2\begin{equation*} \left.\beta \mathcal{H}_{T}=\frac{\mu}{2} \int \frac{\mathrm{~d}^{2} \mathbf{q}}{(2 \pi)^{2}} q^{2} u_{T}^{2},\left.\quad \Longrightarrow \quad\langle | u_{T}(\mathbf{q})\right|^{2}\right\rangle=\frac{1}{\mu q^{2}} \tag{8.84} \end{equation*}βHT​=2μ​∫(2π)2 d2q​q2uT2​,⟹⟨∣uT​(q)∣2⟩=μq21​​(8.84)​

(ii) Longitudinal modes with q∥u\mathbf{q} \| \mathbf{u}q∥u have energy

βHL=2μ+λ2∫ d2q(2π)2q2uL2,⟹∣∣uL(q)∣2⟩=1(2μ+λ)q2\begin{equation*} \left.\beta \mathcal{H}_{L}=\frac{2 \mu+\lambda}{2} \int \frac{\mathrm{~d}^{2} \mathbf{q}}{(2 \pi)^{2}} q^{2} u_{L}^{2},\left.\quad \Longrightarrow \quad| | u_{L}(\mathbf{q})\right|^{2}\right\rangle=\frac{1}{(2 \mu+\lambda) q^{2}} \tag{8.85} \end{equation*}βHL​=22μ+λ​∫(2π)2 d2q​q2uL2​,⟹∣∣uL​(q)∣2⟩=(2μ+λ)q21​​(8.85)​

Combining the above results, we find that a general correlation function is given by

⟨ui(q)uj(q′)⟩=(2π)2δ2(q+q′)μq2[δij−μ+λ2μ+λqiqjq2]\begin{equation*} \left\langle u_{i}(\mathbf{q}) u_{j}\left(\mathbf{q}^{\prime}\right)\right\rangle=\frac{(2 \pi)^{2} \delta^{2}\left(\mathbf{q}+\mathbf{q}^{\prime}\right)}{\mu q^{2}}\left[\delta_{i j}-\frac{\mu+\lambda}{2 \mu+\lambda} \frac{q_{i} q_{j}}{q^{2}}\right] \tag{8.86} \end{equation*}⟨ui​(q)uj​(q′)⟩=μq2(2π)2δ2(q+q′)​[δij​−2μ+λμ+λ​q2qi​qj​​]​(8.86)​

The extent of fluctuations in position space is given by

⟨[u(x)−u(0)]2⟩=∫d2q(2π)22−2cos⁡(q⋅x)μq2[δii−μ+λ2μ+λqiqiq2]=3μ+λμ(2μ+λ)ln⁡(∣x∣/a)π.\begin{align*} \left\langle[\mathbf{u}(\mathbf{x})-\mathbf{u}(\mathbf{0})]^{2}\right\rangle & =\int \frac{\mathrm{d}^{2} \mathbf{q}}{(2 \pi)^{2}} \frac{2-2 \cos (\mathbf{q} \cdot \mathbf{x})}{\mu q^{2}}\left[\delta_{i i}-\frac{\mu+\lambda}{2 \mu+\lambda} \frac{q_{i} q_{i}}{q^{2}}\right] \\ & =\frac{3 \mu+\lambda}{\mu(2 \mu+\lambda)} \frac{\ln (|\mathbf{x}| / a)}{\pi} . \tag{8.87} \end{align*}⟨[u(x)−u(0)]2⟩​=∫(2π)2d2q​μq22−2cos(q⋅x)​[δii​−2μ+λμ+λ​q2qi​qi​​]=μ(2μ+λ)3μ+λ​πln(∣x∣/a)​.​(8.87)​

The unbounded growth of fluctuations with ∣x∣|\mathbf{x}|∣x∣ indicates the destruction of longrange translational order in two dimensions. A similar calculation in higher dimensions results in a finite maximum extent of fluctuations proportional to temperature. The Lindemann criterion identifies the melting point heuristically as the temperature for which these thermal fluctuations reach a fraction (roughly 0.1 ) of the perfect lattice spacing. According to this criterion, the two-dimensional solid melts at any finite temperature. This is of coarse another manifestation of the general absence of true long-range order in two dimensions. Is some form of quasi-long range order, similar to the XY model, possible in this case? (d) The order parameter describing broken translational symmetry is ρG(x)=eiG⋅r(x)\rho_{\mathbf{G}}(\mathbf{x})=\mathrm{e}^{\mathrm{i} \mathbf{G} \cdot \mathbf{r}(\mathbf{x})}ρG​(x)=eiG⋅r(x), where G\mathbf{G}G is any reciprocal lattice vector. Since G⋅r0\mathbf{G} \cdot \mathbf{r}_{0}G⋅r0​ is an integer multiple of 2π2 \pi2π by definition, ρG=1\rho_{\mathbf{G}}=1ρG​=1 at zero temperature. Due to fluctuations ⟨ρG(x)⟩=⟨eiG⋅u(x)⟩\left\langle\rho_{\mathbf{G}}(\mathbf{x})\right\rangle=\left\langle\mathrm{e}^{\mathrm{i} \mathbf{G} \cdot \mathbf{u}(\mathbf{x})}\right\rangle⟨ρG​(x)⟩=⟨eiG⋅u(x)⟩ decreases at finite temperatures, and its correlations decay as

⟨ρG(x)ρG∗(0)⟩=⟨eiG⋅(u(x)−u(0))⟩=exp⁡(−GαGβ2⟨(uα(x)−uα(0))(uβ(x)−uβ(0))⟩)=exp⁡{−GαGβ2∫ d2q d2q′(2π)2(eiq⋅x−1)(eiq′⋅x−1)⟨uα(q)uβ(q′))}=exp⁡{−12∫ d2q(2π)22−2cos⁡q⋅xq2(G2μ−μ+λμ(2μ+λ)(G⋅q)2q2)}≈exp⁡{−G2(3μ+λ)2μ(2μ+λ)ln⁡(∣x∣/a)2π}=(a∣x∣)ηG.\begin{align*} \left\langle\rho_{\mathbf{G}}(\mathbf{x}) \rho_{\mathbf{G}}^{*}(\mathbf{0})\right\rangle & =\left\langle\mathrm{e}^{i \mathbf{G} \cdot(\mathbf{u}(\mathbf{x})-\mathbf{u}(\mathbf{0}))}\right\rangle \\ & =\exp \left(-\frac{G_{\alpha} G_{\beta}}{2}\left\langle\left(u_{\alpha}(\mathbf{x})-u_{\alpha}(\mathbf{0})\right)\left(u_{\beta}(\mathbf{x})-u_{\beta}(\mathbf{0})\right)\right\rangle\right) \\ & =\exp \left\{-\frac{G_{\alpha} G_{\beta}}{2} \int \frac{\mathrm{~d}^{2} \mathbf{q} \mathrm{~d}^{2} \mathbf{q}^{\prime}}{(2 \pi)^{2}}\left(\mathrm{e}^{\mathrm{i} \mathbf{q} \cdot \mathbf{x}}-1\right)\left(\mathrm{e}^{\mathrm{i} \mathbf{q}^{\prime} \cdot \mathbf{x}}-1\right)\left\langle u_{\alpha}(\mathbf{q}) u_{\beta}\left(\mathbf{q}^{\prime}\right)\right)\right\} \\ & =\exp \left\{-\frac{1}{2} \int \frac{\mathrm{~d}^{2} \mathbf{q}}{(2 \pi)^{2}} \frac{2-2 \cos \mathbf{q} \cdot \mathbf{x}}{q^{2}}\left(\frac{G^{2}}{\mu}-\frac{\mu+\lambda}{\mu(2 \mu+\lambda)} \frac{(\mathbf{G} \cdot \mathbf{q})^{2}}{q^{2}}\right)\right\} \\ & \approx \exp \left\{-\frac{G^{2}(3 \mu+\lambda)}{2 \mu(2 \mu+\lambda)} \frac{\ln (|\mathbf{x}| / a)}{2 \pi}\right\}=\left(\frac{a}{|\mathbf{x}|}\right)^{\eta_{G}} . \tag{8.88} \end{align*}⟨ρG​(x)ρG∗​(0)⟩​=⟨eiG⋅(u(x)−u(0))⟩=exp(−2Gα​Gβ​​⟨(uα​(x)−uα​(0))(uβ​(x)−uβ​(0))⟩)=exp{−2Gα​Gβ​​∫(2π)2 d2q d2q′​(eiq⋅x−1)(eiq′⋅x−1)⟨uα​(q)uβ​(q′))}=exp{−21​∫(2π)2 d2q​q22−2cosq⋅x​(μG2​−μ(2μ+λ)μ+λ​q2(G⋅q)2​)}≈exp{−2μ(2μ+λ)G2(3μ+λ)​2πln(∣x∣/a)​}=(∣x∣a​)ηG​.​(8.88)​

The integration over q\mathbf{q}q is performed after replacing (G⋅q)2(\mathbf{G} \cdot \mathbf{q})^{2}(G⋅q)2 with the angular average of G2q2/2G^{2} q^{2} / 2G2q2/2. This is not strictly correct because of the presence of the term cos⁡q⋅x\cos \mathbf{q} \cdot \mathbf{x}cosq⋅x which breaks the rotational symmetry. Nevertheless, this approximation captures the correct asymptotic growth of the integral. Correlations thus decay algebraically with an exponent

ηG=G2(3μ+λ)4πμ(2μ+λ)\begin{equation*} \eta_{G}=\frac{G^{2}(3 \mu+\lambda)}{4 \pi \mu(2 \mu+\lambda)} \tag{8.89} \end{equation*}ηG​=4πμ(2μ+λ)G2(3μ+λ)​​(8.89)​

The translational correlations are measured in diffraction experiments. The scattering amplitude is the Fourier transform of ρq\rho_{\mathbf{q}}ρq​, and the scattered intensity at a wavevector q\mathbf{q}q is proportional to the structure factor

S(q)=⟨∣A(q)∣2⟩=⟨∣∑m,neiq⋅r(m,n)∣2⟩=N∑m,n⟨eiq⋅(r(m,n)−r(0,0))⟩=N∑m,neiq⋅(r0(m,n)−r0(0,0))⟨eiq⋅(u(x)−u(0)⟩\begin{align*} S(\mathbf{q}) & \left.\left.=\left.\langle | A(\mathbf{q})\right|^{2}\right\rangle=\left.\langle | \sum_{m, n} \mathrm{e}^{\mathbf{i q} \cdot \mathbf{r}(m, n)}\right|^{2}\right\rangle=N \sum_{m, n}\left\langle\mathrm{e}^{\mathrm{i} \mathbf{q} \cdot(\mathbf{r}(m, n)-\mathbf{r}(0,0))}\right\rangle \tag{8.90}\\ & =N \sum_{m, n} \mathrm{e}^{\mathrm{i} \mathbf{q} \cdot\left(\mathbf{r}_{0}(m, n)-\mathbf{r}_{0}(0,0)\right)}\left\langle\mathrm{e}^{\mathrm{i} \mathbf{q} \cdot(\mathbf{u}(\mathbf{x})-\mathbf{u}(\mathbf{0})}\right\rangle \end{align*}S(q)​=⟨∣A(q)∣2⟩=⟨∣m,n∑​eiq⋅r(m,n)​2⟩=Nm,n∑​⟨eiq⋅(r(m,n)−r(0,0))⟩=Nm,n∑​eiq⋅(r0​(m,n)−r0​(0,0))⟨eiq⋅(u(x)−u(0)⟩​(8.90)​

where NNN is the total number of particles. At zero temperature, the structure factor is a set of delta-functions (Bragg peaks) at the reciprocal lattice vectors. Even at finite temperature the sum is zero due to varying phases, unless q\mathbf{q}q is in the vicinity of a lattice vector G\mathbf{G}G. We can then replace the sum with an integral, and

S(q≈G)≈N∫ d2xei(q−G)⋅x(a∣x∣)ηG≈N∣q−G∣2−ηG\begin{equation*} S(\mathbf{q} \approx \mathbf{G}) \approx N \int \mathrm{~d}^{2} \mathbf{x e}^{\mathrm{i}(\mathbf{q}-\mathbf{G}) \cdot \mathbf{x}}\left(\frac{a}{|\mathbf{x}|}\right)^{\eta_{\mathbf{G}}} \approx \frac{N}{|\mathbf{q}-\mathbf{G}|^{2-\eta_{\mathbf{G}}}} \tag{8.91} \end{equation*}S(q≈G)≈N∫ d2xei(q−G)⋅x(∣x∣a​)ηG​≈∣q−G∣2−ηG​N​​(8.91)​

The Bragg peaks are now replaced by power law singularities. The strength of the divergence decreases with temperature and increasing ∣G∣|\mathbf{G}|∣G∣. The peaks corresponding to sufficiently large ∣G∣|\mathbf{G}|∣G∣ are no longer visible, and gradually more of them disappear on increasing temperature. In three dimensions, the structure factor is still a set of delta-functions, but with magnitudes diminished by the so called Debye-Waller factor of exp⁡(−G212πa5μ+2λμ(2μ+λ))\exp \left(-\frac{G^{2}}{12 \pi a} \frac{5 \mu+2 \lambda}{\mu(2 \mu+\lambda)}\right)exp(−12πaG2​μ(2μ+λ)5μ+2λ​). (e) The crystal phase is also characterized by a broken rotational symmetry. We can define an orientational order parameter Ψ(x)=e6ii(x)\Psi(\mathbf{x})=\mathrm{e}^{6 \mathrm{ii}(\mathbf{x})}Ψ(x)=e6ii(x), where θ(x)\theta(\mathbf{x})θ(x) is the angle between local lattice bonds and a reference axis. (The factor of 6 results from the equivalence of the six possible directions on the triangular lattice. The appropriate choice for a square lattice is e4iθ(x)\mathrm{e}^{4 i \theta(\mathbf{x})}e4iθ(x).) The order parameter has unit magnitude at T=0T=0T=0, and is expected to decrease due to fluctuations at finite temperature.
