The distortion u(x)\mathbf{u}(\mathbf{x})u(x) leads to a change in bond angle given by

θ(x)=−12(∂uy∂x−∂ux∂y)=−12z^⋅∇×u.\begin{equation*} \theta(\mathbf{x})=-\frac{1}{2}\left(\frac{\partial u_{y}}{\partial x}-\frac{\partial u_{x}}{\partial y}\right)=-\frac{1}{2} \widehat{z} \cdot \nabla \times \mathbf{u} . \tag{8.92} \end{equation*}θ(x)=−21​(∂x∂uy​​−∂y∂ux​​)=−21​z⋅∇×u.​(8.92)​

The decay of orientational fluctuations is now calculated from

⟨Ψ(x)Ψ∗(0)⟩=⟨ei(θ(θ(x)−θ(0))⟩=exp⁡[−62214⟨[∇×u(x)−∇×u(0)]2⟩]=exp⁡{−92∫ d2q d2q′(2π)4(eiq⋅x−1)(eiq′⋅x−1)εijkεij′k′qjqj′′⟨uk(q)uk′(q′)⟩}=exp⁡{−92∫ d2q(2π)2(2−2cos⁡q⋅x)(q2⟨∣u(q)∣2⟩−⟨(q⋅u)2⟩)}=exp⁡{−92μ∫ d2q(2π)2(2−2cos⁡q⋅x)}≈exp⁡(−9a2μ)\begin{align*} \left\langle\Psi(\mathbf{x}) \Psi^{*}(0)\right\rangle & =\left\langle\mathrm{e}^{\mathrm{i}(\theta(\theta(\mathbf{x})-\theta(\mathbf{0}))}\right\rangle \\ & =\exp \left[-\frac{6^{2}}{2} \frac{1}{4}\left\langle[\nabla \times \mathbf{u}(\mathbf{x})-\nabla \times \mathbf{u}(\mathbf{0})]^{2}\right\rangle\right] \\ & =\exp \left\{-\frac{9}{2} \int \frac{\mathrm{~d}^{2} \mathbf{q} \mathrm{~d}^{2} \mathbf{q}^{\prime}}{(2 \pi)^{4}}\left(\mathrm{e}^{\mathrm{i} \mathbf{q} \cdot \mathbf{x}}-1\right)\left(\mathrm{e}^{\mathrm{i} \mathbf{q}^{\prime} \cdot \mathbf{x}}-1\right) \varepsilon_{i j k} \varepsilon_{i j^{\prime} k^{\prime}} q_{j} q_{j^{\prime}}^{\prime}\left\langle u_{k}(\mathbf{q}) u_{k^{\prime}}\left(\mathbf{q}^{\prime}\right)\right\rangle\right\} \\ & \left.=\exp \left\{-\frac{9}{2} \int \frac{\mathrm{~d}^{2} \mathbf{q}}{(2 \pi)^{2}}(2-2 \cos \mathbf{q} \cdot \mathbf{x})\left(\left.q^{2}\langle | u(\mathbf{q})\right|^{2}\right\rangle-\left\langle(\mathbf{q} \cdot \mathbf{u})^{2}\right\rangle\right)\right\} \\ & =\exp \left\{-\frac{9}{2 \mu} \int \frac{\mathrm{~d}^{2} \mathbf{q}}{(2 \pi)^{2}}(2-2 \cos \mathbf{q} \cdot \mathbf{x})\right\} \approx \exp \left(-\frac{9}{a^{2} \mu}\right) \tag{8.93} \end{align*}⟨Ψ(x)Ψ∗(0)⟩​=⟨ei(θ(θ(x)−θ(0))⟩=exp[−262​41​⟨[∇×u(x)−∇×u(0)]2⟩]=exp{−29​∫(2π)4 d2q d2q′​(eiq⋅x−1)(eiq′⋅x−1)εijk​εij′k′​qj​qj′′​⟨uk​(q)uk′​(q′)⟩}=exp{−29​∫(2π)2 d2q​(2−2cosq⋅x)(q2⟨∣u(q)​2⟩−⟨(q⋅u)2⟩)}=exp{−2μ9​∫(2π)2 d2q​(2−2cosq⋅x)}≈exp(−a2μ9​)​(8.93)​

(Note that ∫d2q/(2π)2\int \mathrm{d}^{2} \mathbf{q} /(2 \pi)^{2}∫d2q/(2π)2 is the density n=N/L2=1/a2n=N / L^{2}=1 / a^{2}n=N/L2=1/a2.) The final result is independent of x\mathbf{x}x at large distances, and asymptotes to a constant that decays exponentially with temperature (since μ∝1/T\mu \propto 1 / Tμ∝1/T ). The two-dimensional solid is thus characterized by quasi-long range translational order, and true long range orientational order.

8.5 Two-dimensional melting

There are qualitative similarities between the melting of a two-dimensional solid and the disordering of the XY spin system. Expanding on the work of Kosterlitz and Thouless [J. Phys. C 5, L124 (1972)], Halperin and Nelson [Phys. Rev. Lett. 41, 121 (1978)], and independently, Young [Phys. Rev. B 19,

Fig. 8.7 Examples of dislocations, and the corresponding Burger's vectors, on the triangular and square lattices.

1855 (1978)], developed a theory of two-dimensional melting. The resulting, so-called KTHNY theory is briefly sketched here. (a) The topological defects of a solid are dislocations. A single dislocation corresponds to an extra half lattice plane, and is characterized by performing a Burger's circuit: The circuit is a series of steps from site to site that on a perfect lattice returns to the starting point (e.g. five steps to the right, four down, followed by five left, and four up on a square lattice.) If the circuit encloses a region with dislocations, it will fail to close. The difference between the initial and final sites of the circuit defines b, the Burger's vector of the dislocation. This closure failure is possible since the distortion field u(x)\mathbf{u}(\mathbf{x})u(x) is defined only up to a lattice vector. In terms of the continuous distortion field this closure failure is described by

∮∇uαds=bα.\begin{equation*} \oint \nabla u_{\alpha} \mathrm{d} \mathbf{s}=b^{\alpha} . \tag{8.94} \end{equation*}∮∇uα​ds=bα.​(8.94)​

Thus each component of the distortion field behaves like the angle θ(x)\theta(\mathbf{x})θ(x) in the XY model. Using this analogy, a possible distortion field due to a collection of dislocations {bi}\left\{\mathbf{b}_{i}\right\}{bi​}, at locations {xi}\left\{\mathbf{x}_{i}\right\}{xi​}, has a singular part

∇u~α∗=−∇×(z^∑ibiα2πln⁡∣x−xi∣)\begin{equation*} \nabla \widetilde{u}_{\alpha}^{*}=-\nabla \times\left(\widehat{z} \sum_{i} \frac{b_{i}^{\alpha}}{2 \pi} \ln \left|\mathbf{x}-\mathbf{x}_{i}\right|\right) \tag{8.95} \end{equation*}∇uα∗​=−∇×(zi∑​2πbiα​​ln∣x−xi​∣)​(8.95)​

While the above u~α∗\widetilde{u}_{\alpha}^{*}uα∗​ correctly describes the singularities due to the presence of dislocations, it is not a local equilibrium configuration, i.e. not a solution to 2μu~αβ+λδαβu~γγ=02 \mu \widetilde{u}_{\alpha \beta}+\lambda \delta_{\alpha \beta} \widetilde{u}_{\gamma \gamma}=02μuαβ​+λδαβ​uγγ​=0. Allowing the particles to equilibrate in the presence of the dislocations leads to a solution u~α\widetilde{u}_{\alpha}uα​, which differs from u~α∗\widetilde{u}_{\alpha}^{*}uα∗​ only by a regular part. The total strain field can now decomposed as uαβ=ϕαβ+u~αβu_{\alpha \beta}=\phi_{\alpha \beta}+\widetilde{u}_{\alpha \beta}uαβ​=ϕαβ​+uαβ​, where u~αβ\widetilde{u}_{\alpha \beta}uαβ​ results from dislocations, and ϕαβ\phi_{\alpha \beta}ϕαβ​ is the contribution of phonons. After substituting this form in the elastic energy βH=∫d2x[2μuαβuαβ+λuααuββ]/2\beta \mathcal{H}=\int \mathrm{d}^{2} \mathbf{x}\left[2 \mu u_{\alpha \beta} u_{\alpha \beta}+\lambda u_{\alpha \alpha} u_{\beta \beta}\right] / 2βH=∫d2x[2μuαβ​uαβ​+λuαα​uββ​]/2, manipulations similar to the XY model lead to βH=βH0+βH1\beta \mathcal{H}=\beta \mathcal{H}_{0}+\beta \mathcal{H}_{1}βH=βH0​+βH1​, where

βH0=12∫ d2x[2μϕαβϕαβ+λϕααϕββ]\begin{equation*} \beta \mathcal{H}_{0}=\frac{1}{2} \int \mathrm{~d}^{2} \mathbf{x}\left[2 \mu \phi_{\alpha \beta} \phi_{\alpha \beta}+\lambda \phi_{\alpha \alpha} \phi_{\beta \beta}\right] \tag{8.96} \end{equation*}βH0​=21​∫ d2x[2μϕαβ​ϕαβ​+λϕαα​ϕββ​]​(8.96)​

and

βH1=−Kˉ∑i<jbiαbjβCαβ(xi−xj)−∑iln⁡[y0(bi)]\begin{equation*} \beta \mathcal{H}_{1}=-\bar{K} \sum_{i<j} b_{i}^{\alpha} b_{j}^{\beta} C_{\alpha \beta}\left(\mathbf{x}_{i}-\mathbf{x}_{j}\right)-\sum_{i} \ln \left[y_{0}\left(\mathbf{b}_{i}\right)\right] \tag{8.97} \end{equation*}βH1​=−Kˉi<j∑​biα​bjβ​Cαβ​(xi​−xj​)−i∑​ln[y0​(bi​)]​(8.97)​

The dislocations behave as a grand canonical gas of particles with vector charges {bi}\left\{\mathbf{b}_{i}\right\}{bi​}. The fugacity y0y_{0}y0​ comes from the core energy of each dislocation. These charges interact via a vectorial generalization of the Coulomb interaction,

Cαβ(x)=12π[δαβln⁡(∣x∣a)−xαxβx2]\begin{equation*} C_{\alpha \beta}(\mathbf{x})=\frac{1}{2 \pi}\left[\delta_{\alpha \beta} \ln \left(\frac{|\mathbf{x}|}{a}\right)-\frac{x_{\alpha} x_{\beta}}{x^{2}}\right] \tag{8.98} \end{equation*}Cαβ​(x)=2π1​[δαβ​ln(a∣x∣​)−x2xα​xβ​​]​(8.98)​

The strength of the interaction in Eq. (8.97) is Kˉa2=2μ(μ+λ)/(2μ+λ)\bar{K} a^{2}=2 \mu(\mu+\lambda) /(2 \mu+\lambda)Kˉa2=2μ(μ+λ)/(2μ+λ). Implicit in the above derivation is an overall neutrality condition, ∑ibi=0\sum_{i} \mathbf{b}_{i}=\mathbf{0}∑i​bi​=0.

The bare interaction between dislocations is screened by other dislocations in the medium. As in the case of vortices, an effective strength can be calculated perturbatively in y0y_{0}y0​. The perturbative correction, however, diverges for πKˉa2<2\pi \bar{K} a^{2}<2πKˉa2<2, signaling the unbinding of paired neutral dislocations. Under coarse graining, the parameters of the theory evolve as

{dKˉ−1 dℓ=Ay2+By3 dy0 dℓ=(2−πKˉ)y+Dy2(8.99)\left\{\begin{array}{l} \frac{\mathrm{d} \bar{K}^{-1}}{\mathrm{~d} \ell}=A y^{2}+B y^{3} \tag{8.99}\\ \frac{\mathrm{~d} y_{0}}{\mathrm{~d} \ell}=(2-\pi \bar{K}) y+D y^{2} \end{array}\right.{ dℓdKˉ−1​=Ay2+By3 dℓ dy0​​=(2−πKˉ)y+Dy2​(8.99)

where A,BA, BA,B, and DDD are constants. In contrast to the XY model, additional terms appear at order of y03y_{0}^{3}y03​. This is because in a scalar Coulomb gas the only neutral configurations have an even number of particles. For dislocations on a triangular lattice, it is possible to construct a neutral configuration from three dislocations at 120∘120^{\circ}120∘ angles.

The low-temperature phase maps onto a line of fixed points characterized by renormalized Lamé coefficients, μR\mu_{R}μR​ and λR\lambda_{R}λR​, and y0∗=0y_{0}^{*}=0y0∗​=0. At high temperatures y0y_{0}y0​ and Kˉ\bar{K}Kˉ both diverge, indicating the vanishing of the shear modulus μR\mu_{R}μR​, and a finite correlation length ξ\xiξ. On approaching the transition from the low-temperature side, the effective shear modulus undergoes a discontinuous jump, with a singular behavior, μR≃μc+c(Tc−T)νˉ\mu_{R} \simeq \mu_{c}+c\left(T_{c}-T\right)^{\bar{\nu}}μR​≃μc​+c(Tc​−T)νˉ. The correlation length diverges from the hightemperature side as ξ≃aexp⁡(c′/(T−Tc)νˉ)\xi \simeq a \exp \left(c^{\prime} /\left(T-T_{c}\right)^{\bar{\nu}}\right)ξ≃aexp(c′/(T−Tc​)νˉ). Due to the cubic terms appearing in Eqs. (8.99), the value of νˉ=0.36963⋯\bar{\nu}=0.36963 \cdotsνˉ=0.36963⋯ is different from the 1/21 / 21/2 that appears in the XY model, indicating a difference between transitions in vector and scalar Coulomb universality classes [Nelson and Halperin, Phys. Rev. B 19, 2457 (1979)]. (b) Does the vanishing of the shear modulus imply that the high temperature phase with unbound dislocations is a liquid? As discussed earlier, the crystalline phase has both translational and orientational order. A distortion u(x)\mathbf{u}(\mathbf{x})u(x) results in a rotation in bond angles according to Eq. (8.92). The net rotation due to a collection of dislocations is

θ~(x)=−12z^⋅∇×u~=12π∑ibi⋅(x−xi)∣x−xi∣2\begin{equation*} \widetilde{\theta}(\mathbf{x})=-\frac{1}{2} \widehat{z} \cdot \nabla \times \widetilde{u}=\frac{1}{2 \pi} \sum_{i} \frac{\mathbf{b}_{i} \cdot\left(\mathbf{x}-\mathbf{x}_{i}\right)}{\left|\mathbf{x}-\mathbf{x}_{i}\right|^{2}} \tag{8.100} \end{equation*}θ(x)=−21​z⋅∇×u=2π1​i∑​∣x−xi​∣2bi​⋅(x−xi​)​​(8.100)​

In terms of a continuum dislocation density b(x)=∑ibiδ2(x−xi)\mathbf{b}(\mathbf{x})=\sum_{i} \mathbf{b}_{i} \delta^{2}\left(\mathbf{x}-\mathbf{x}_{i}\right)b(x)=∑i​bi​δ2(x−xi​),

θ~(x)=12π∫ d2x′b(x′)⋅(x−x′)∣x−x′∣2\begin{equation*} \widetilde{\theta}(\mathbf{x})=\frac{1}{2 \pi} \int \mathrm{~d}^{2} \mathbf{x}^{\prime} \frac{\mathbf{b}\left(\mathbf{x}^{\prime}\right) \cdot\left(\mathbf{x}-\mathbf{x}^{\prime}\right)}{\left|\mathbf{x}-\mathbf{x}^{\prime}\right|^{2}} \tag{8.101} \end{equation*}θ(x)=2π1​∫ d2x′∣x−x′∣2b(x′)⋅(x−x′)​​(8.101)​

Alternatively, in Fourier space,

θ~(q)=∫d2xd2x′eiq⋅xb(x′)⋅(x−x′)2π∣x−x′∣2=ib(q)⋅qq2\begin{equation*} \widetilde{\theta}(\mathbf{q})=\int \mathrm{d}^{2} \mathbf{x d}^{2} \mathbf{x}^{\prime} \mathrm{e}^{\mathrm{i} \mathbf{q} \cdot \mathbf{x}} \frac{b\left(\mathbf{x}^{\prime}\right) \cdot\left(\mathbf{x}-\mathbf{x}^{\prime}\right)}{2 \pi\left|\mathbf{x}-\mathbf{x}^{\prime}\right|^{2}}=\mathrm{i} \frac{\mathbf{b}(\mathbf{q}) \cdot \mathbf{q}}{q^{2}} \tag{8.102} \end{equation*}θ(q)=∫d2xd2x′eiq⋅x2π∣x−x′∣2b(x′)⋅(x−x′)​=iq2b(q)⋅q​​(8.102)​

The angular fluctuations are thus related to correlations in dislocation density via

⟨∣θ~(q)∣2⟩=qαqβq4⟨bα(q)bβ(q)⟩\begin{equation*} \left.\left.\langle | \widetilde{\theta}(\mathbf{q})\right|^{2}\right\rangle=\frac{q_{\alpha} q_{\beta}}{q^{4}}\left\langle b^{\alpha}(\mathbf{q}) b^{\beta}(\mathbf{q})\right\rangle \tag{8.103} \end{equation*}⟨∣θ(q)​2⟩=q4qα​qβ​​⟨bα(q)bβ(q)⟩​(8.103)​

where

⟨bα(q)bβ(q)⟩=∫d2xeiq⋅x⟨bα(x)bβ(0)⟩\begin{equation*} \left\langle b^{\alpha}(\mathbf{q}) b^{\beta}(\mathbf{q})\right\rangle=\int \mathrm{d}^{2} \mathbf{x} \mathrm{e}^{\mathrm{i} \mathbf{q} \cdot \mathbf{x}}\left\langle b^{\alpha}(\mathbf{x}) b^{\beta}(\mathbf{0})\right\rangle \tag{8.104} \end{equation*}⟨bα(q)bβ(q)⟩=∫d2xeiq⋅x⟨bα(x)bβ(0)⟩​(8.104)​

After the dislocations are unbound for T>TcT>T_{c}T>Tc​, they interact via a screened Coulomb interaction, and

lim⁡∣x∣→∞⟨bα(x)bβ(0)⟩∝δαβe−∣x∣/ξ,⟹lim⁡q→0⟨bα(q)bβ(q)⟩∝δαβξ2\begin{equation*} \lim _{|\mathbf{x}| \rightarrow \infty}\left\langle b^{\alpha}(\mathbf{x}) b^{\beta}(\mathbf{0})\right\rangle \propto \delta_{\alpha \beta} e^{-|\mathbf{x}| / \xi}, \Longrightarrow \lim _{\mathbf{q} \rightarrow \mathbf{0}}\left\langle b^{\alpha}(\mathbf{q}) b^{\beta}(\mathbf{q})\right\rangle \propto \delta_{\alpha \beta} \xi^{2} \tag{8.105} \end{equation*}∣x∣→∞lim​⟨bα(x)bβ(0)⟩∝δαβ​e−∣x∣/ξ,⟹q→0lim​⟨bα(q)bβ(q)⟩∝δαβ​ξ2​(8.105)​

Substituting into Eq. (8.103) leads to

lim⁡q→0⟨∣θ~(q)∣2⟩∝ξ2q2\begin{equation*} \left.\left.\lim _{\mathbf{q} \rightarrow \mathbf{0}}\langle | \widetilde{\theta}(\mathbf{q})\right|^{2}\right\rangle \propto \frac{\xi^{2}}{q^{2}} \tag{8.106} \end{equation*}q→0lim​⟨∣θ(q)​2⟩∝q2ξ2​​(8.106)​

(In the low-temperature phase, the neutrality of the charges at a large scale ∣q∣−1|\mathbf{q}|^{-1}∣q∣−1 requires the vanishing of b(q)\mathbf{b}(\mathbf{q})b(q) as q→0\mathbf{q} \rightarrow \mathbf{0}q→0, and lim⁡q→0⟨bα(q)bβ(q)⟩∝qαqβ\lim _{\mathbf{q} \rightarrow \mathbf{0}}\left\langle b^{\alpha}(\mathbf{q}) b^{\beta}(\mathbf{q})\right\rangle \propto q_{\alpha} q_{\beta}limq→0​⟨bα(q)bβ(q)⟩∝qα​qβ​, leading to a finite ⟨∣θ~(q)∣2⟩\left.\left.\langle | \widetilde{\theta}(\mathbf{q})\right|^{2}\right\rangle⟨∣θ(q)​2⟩.)

Equation (8.106) implies that after the unbinding of dislocations the orientational fluctuations are still correlated. In fact such correlations would result from a Hamiltonian

βH=KA2∫ d2x(∇θ)2, with KA∝ξ2\begin{equation*} \beta \mathcal{H}=\frac{K_{A}}{2} \int \mathrm{~d}^{2} \mathbf{x}(\nabla \theta)^{2}, \quad \text { with } \quad K_{A} \propto \xi^{2} \tag{8.107} \end{equation*}βH=2KA​​∫ d2x(∇θ)2, with KA​∝ξ2​(8.107)​

The angular stiffness KAK_{A}KA​ is known as the Frank constant. The bond angle order correlations now decay as

⟨Ψ(x)Ψ∗(0)⟩=e−362⟨[θ~(x)−θ~(0)]2⟩=(a∣x∣)−ηΨ\begin{equation*} \left\langle\Psi(\mathbf{x}) \Psi^{*}(\mathbf{0})\right\rangle=\mathrm{e}^{-\frac{36}{2}\left\langle[\widetilde{\theta}(\mathbf{x})-\widetilde{\theta}(\mathbf{0})]^{2}\right\rangle}=\left(\frac{a}{|\mathbf{x}|}\right)^{-\eta_{\Psi}} \tag{8.108} \end{equation*}⟨Ψ(x)Ψ∗(0)⟩=e−236​⟨[θ(x)−θ(0)]2⟩=(∣x∣a​)−ηΨ​​(8.108)​

with ηΨ=18/(πKA)\eta_{\Psi}=18 /\left(\pi K_{A}\right)ηΨ​=18/(πKA​). The quasi-long range decay of orientational fluctuations leads to the appearance of a six-fold intensity modulation in the diffraction pattern. The dislocations are thus not effective in completely destroying order, and their unbinding leads to the appearance of an orientationally ordered phase known as a hexatic. The stiffness of the hexatic phase diverges at the transition to a solid according to Eq. (8.107). (c) Orientational order disappears at a higher temperature due to the unbinding of a new set of topological defects known as disclinations. These are very similar to the vortices in the XY model, except that since the bond angle is defined only up to 2π/62 \pi / 62π/6, they satisfy

∮∇θ⋅ds⃗=2π6.\begin{equation*} \oint \nabla \theta \cdot \mathrm{d} \vec{s}=\frac{2 \pi}{6} . \tag{8.109} \end{equation*}∮∇θ⋅ds=62π​.​(8.109)​

The energy cost of a disclination grows with system size as E1=πKAln⁡(L/a)/36\mathcal{E}_{1}=\pi K_{A} \ln (L / a) / 36E1​=πKA​ln(L/a)/36. Considering the entropy of 2ln⁡(L/a)2 \ln (L / a)2ln(L/a), we find a disclination unbinding transition for KA<72/πK_{A}<72 / \piKA​<72/π. This transition is in the universality class of the scalar Coulomb gas. The resulting high-temperature phase has neither orientational nor translational order and is a conventional liquid.

Fig. 8.8 Two-stage melting of a two-dimensional triangular lattice: The orientational correlation length ξo\xi_{o}ξo​ diverges at the liquid to hexatic transition at T1T_{1}T1​. The hexatic stiffness KKK diverges at the hexatic to solid transition at T2T_{2}T2​. The elastic shear coefficient has a jump at T1T_{1}T1​.

This scenario predicts that the melting of a two-dimensional solid proceeds through an intermediate hexatic phase. In fact, computer simulations suggest that simple two-dimensional solids, e.g. particles interacting via Lennard-Jones potentials, undergo a direct first order melting transition as in three dimensions. More complicated molecular systems in three dimensions, e.g. long polymers, are known to have intermediate liquid crystal phases. Liquid crystals have order intermediate between solid and fluid and are three-dimensional analogs of the hexatic phase. Thin films made up of a few monolayers of liquid crystals are good candidates for examining the KTHNY melting scenario.

  1. Matrix models: In some situations, the order parameter is a matrix rather than a vector.   1. Symmetry breaking fields: Let us investigate adding a term
−βHp=hp∫ d2xcos⁡(pθ(x))-\beta \mathcal{H}_{p}=h_{p} \int \mathrm{~d}^{2} \mathbf{x} \cos (p \theta(\mathbf{x}))−βHp​=hp​∫ d2xcos(pθ(x))

to the XY model.
